div.p: This is a set of rules, which represent the aspects of a personal life as it is experienced in the setting. The story-lines of these lives are separated from the rule-mechanics thereof. Any situation that needs to be resolved with rules, such as conflicts, can be separated into different dimensions. These dimensions are treated individually, but also interact. This “dimensionality” avoids creating constraints in situations that should not have them from an inner-world perspective. Attributes are properties of people that can be observed by knowledgeable observers in the world, just as occupational or professional skills are. They are reasonable abstractions to be made inside the world.

All out-world rules are condensed in this chapter. Any competence in-world are abstracted on a five-star scale ★ through ★★★★★, where exceptional values may go beyond. Minutes and other units more easily measured are applied regularly, but the star scale illustrates the difference. How to turn this into numbers for out-world rule operations is detailed later.

A new type of die roll is introduced. You roll a d5 until you get a 1 and then count the number of dice that did not show up a 1. That is the same as the number of dice you actually rolled minus one. This roll is dominated by the active character, or more generally, the actor. It will generate positive numbers (or zero) and is termed the positive roll and abbreviated as p5. Example: Peter rolls 5, 3, 8, 10, 2 (in that order) on a d10. He simulates the d5 by taking the result of a d10, halving it and rounding up. He thus rolled 3, 2, 4, 5, 1, on a d5 effectively. His p5 roll would be a 4.

Of course, there is a negative roll that is associated with the passive resistance or the impediment. It is handled in the same way but the negative value is taken instead. Thus in the above example, we would take -4 as result of a negative roll; therefore we can simply denote the roll as -p5. These two numbers (from different rolls) are added. The result will be a whole number, called n5 (n for neutral). An understanding of this rule is crucial, so we elaborate by listing the probabilities involved as well as some examples.

The first row in the following table shows some of the results you can achieve when you roll a p5. The second row shows the chance that you have of moving up one point (i.e. right) at any given point. A p5 can never give a result below zero (0) and the chance to get "one more" is 80%. Note that this chance is always the same in each column. The third row gives the percentage chance that you have of achieving the result in the corresponding first row instead of using the p5 mechanic. These percentages you could use for rolling a d100 to get the same probabilities; maybe in order to reduce the number of dice to roll. All but the first two columns of this third row are approximations. The last column (with the ...) is somewhat special. It combines the “higher” results and is often called exploding in other rule systems. You could expand the table to infinity, if you wanted. While the extensions of the first and second row are quite obvious, the third may not be. It should be interpreted thus: if you roll 91-100, you need to roll again on this (third row of the) table, read of the result as before and then add 10 to the result. (For the mathematically inclined, this is a recursive definition, since it is possible that you roll 91-100 again, which forces you to roll on this table again and add 20 to the net result from the repeated application. We will see this in the examples.)

This table only considers one roll, i.e. the positive. You need to combine both into a single result in most cases. Two key observations useful in the future are: Zero (0) is the expectation value of the combined roll (n5) and five (5) for the single roll (p5). When comparing numbers directly, say skills in a duel, a level 0 skill will only break even (or win) against a level 10 skill in 10% of all cases. This is something that can be estimated in-world, and thus this rule lies at the border of in- and out-world rules.

To improve speed, several d10 may be rolled in ordered fashion. Order them according to size or alphabetical color (e.g. black, blue, green, yellow) or in any other way you can remember. With a d10 stop at 1 or 2. Computer applications that make rolling as easy as pressing a button are easy to program.

ul.li: Assume you decided to use the third row of the table, then rolled a d100, and get a 24 on the positive roll. This means a result of 1. The second roll for the negative part shows a 50, which results in 3. The net result therefore is a -2.
A more exotic roll would be the sequence 96, 99, 93, 61 on the positive d100. That result would be 34 (positive only).

Using the standard method (i.e. the second row with a d5), the positive sequence on a d10 may show 3, 8, 10, 7, 9, 4, 6, 3, 10, 10, 8, 4, 2 and the negative sequence shows 3, 6, 9, 4, 4, 1. The positive result is 12 and the negative -5 with a net result of +7. If you decide that +7 is not precise enough, a roll of 3 and 5 on a d10 (each) gives are finer result of +7.35.

div.p: Active/positive and passive/negative are symmetrical. If you imagine one character stealthily evading another, the first may interpret the rolls as himself actively evading against a passive observation of the surroundings. That is, positive evasion vs. negative observation. The second may interpret the rolls as him actively scrutinizing the vicinity against a passively hiding opponent. That is, positive observation vs. negative evasion. Either way, one roll (or a set of two rolls) will determine the same outcome.

The rolls scale with difficulty. Imagine that one character is particularly strong with a certain skill, but also attempts more difficult tasks. Imagine the child character climbing the neighborhood tree and as a grown, experienced man climbing an overhanging cliff. The child's climbing bonus of 5 against a difficulty addition of 7 for the tree gives the same probability distribution as the adult's bonus of 27 against the cliff's 29. It is easily seen why.

Consider you have two skills of equal value that you want to add together. If the effect of the two skills combined is as good as a skill of n points better, we call that Row-n-Addition. This means that two people of the same skill with value x have a fair (50:50) chance of beating someone with a value x + n in that skill. Taking the maximum of two separate skill rolls is similar to a Row-5-Addition as far as the probabilities are concerned. When using the tables, take the two numbers and use the (positive) difference of the two in the first row, to read of a result in the second, and add this result to the bigger to get the end result. The “real” value to use when precision loss is important to you (rarely) is the math-formula n*ln(1+exp(-d*ln(2)/n))/ln(2), where d is the difference. Since we only intend to use n=3, 5, 7, we provide tables for them. You can also use the automated formula right here. Looking at the tables, you see the reduction in effectiveness when adding smaller numbers to higher ones.
Sometimes, to ease writing, we denote Row-n-Addition with +n, where n=3,5,7, e.g. Row-5-Addition of 1 and 2 is written as 1 +5 2.

In many sections statements effects, durations, fatigue, etc. is mentioned as a skill use or similar. Whenever it is a multiple a 5, it can be subject to a n5 roll. Also see the Dimensions section in the Skills section.

Skills govern all physical and mental activities, such as combat and spell-casting. All skills are derived from character attributes and occupations and rated on open scale starting from zero (0) as the “default”, with only 10% reaching 10 points more. This is inentionally identical with the p5 system of rolling dice. The skill scale is open-ended ("exploding") as the p5 roll is, but humans generally do not get scores beyond 30. Any activity can be organized as a skill.

Skill Base (SB) represents a character’s natural affinity for a skill. The SB for each skill can be calculated when necessary. It is unlikely this varies after the beginning of play. A skill is tested, when its application becomes useful or meaningful (a decision by the GM). Some skills should be predetermined, because their application is hard to avoid. Each skill entry below lists the attributes for its base. To determine an SB, the attributes are averaged. If an attribute is listed twice, it is counted twice in the calculation. Then directly subtract 15. If the character’s Sunsign is listed, it increases SB by the indicated number – this is not averaged, but only applied directly as part of the SB.

Mastery Level (ML) represents a character’s current competence at a specific skill; the higher the number, the more skillful. MLs may be improved in the course of play and range from 0 to 30 usually. Technically, there is no limit.

Opening Mastery Level (OML) is listed with each skill. This is the starting point for any skill ML. Many skill start at zero (0) and can immediately be improved. (in the fashion described below). If the number is negative, any improvement of the skill can only happen with a teacher. Once an ML reaches zero (0) this restriction no longer applies.
Effective Mastery Level (EML) is SB +5 ML. It can very with time. Other bonuses and penalties may be added in concrete situations.

Every skill in the list has an Occupation entry. It shows a list of occupations with a percentage value each. If an occupation is listed, then the OML listed is not used, but instead the Occupation ML times the percentage listed. Multiple occupations are combined through Row-5-Addition. Example: Juryn has an SB in Dancing of 4. The occupation listing of 40 for his profession where he has level (ML) 20. Thus his OML is 20 x 40% = 8 and his starting EML is SB +5 ML = 8 +5 4 = 11.

Many skills can be divided into sub-skills or specialties; suggestions are given with some skills. Characters may select specialties at any time. The skill is then termed a group skill and included all (potential) specialties, even if unknown. The specific specialty skill is opened at the current group ML. Each specialty is developed as a separate skill. A character may declare any number of specialties, but each is a separate skill. Example: Bjorni has Sword skill at ML 14. He decides to choose Broadsword as a specialty. Sword and Broadsword are now two separate skills. Bjorni must use his current Sword skill if he uses any other sword than Browadsword.

Sometimes, only Specialties are given and the question arises, what ML in the Specialty implies on the skill group. Each specialty has a percentage value associated with it. (For a new Specialty, this must be decided upon by the GM.) Take that percentage of Specialty ML to get the group's ML. For example, a Mask/20% specialty in Woodcraft of 12 would imply a Woodcraft group score of 2.4, rounded down to 2.
Note that this section applies to ML, not OML or EML. EML is calculated regularly as for any skill and OML (if specialization is attempted at the outset) is as for the group skill.

EML is modified for a concrete test, because of fatigue, injury, encumbrance, or difficult (or easy) circumstance Example: a character might normally have a minimum 0 in Climbing. However, climbing an ice cliff, with a broken arm, during a blizzard is probably impossible, and the GM may feel an ML of -30 is justified. (This is roughly a 1 in 1000 chance of succeeding.) If instead she was trying to decipher an alien script (without access to some sort of comparison) the ML may be at -50. (This is roughly a 1 in 100,000 chance of succeeding.) Factors affecting EML are sometimes specified in the skill description; otherwise GM discretion applies.

When a character attempts to use a skill, n5 is rolled. Add/Subtract EML and any other modifiers the GM has noted. Some modifiers are "standard" and listed below, they will not be mentioned explicitely. The GM will have decided upon a diffculty, often called the negative part. This value is also subtracted from the roll and if the net result is not-negative, the skill has been successfully employed; if the roll is negative, the attempt has failed. For example, if a PC declares the intent to perform a gymnastic feat, the GM would instruct the player to “test Acrobatics against difficulty 15.” In cases where success or failure may not be obvious, the GM should make the roll secretly.

It is often necessary to know the degree of success or failure. The skill descriptions provide these so-called dimensions. For skills, where no appropriate success levels are provided or for newly devised skills, estimate the effects by looking at the skills most closely related.

When two characters use skills against each other, each character makes a p5 skill roll appropriate to the skill in question and the success levels are compared to give a net result. The descriptions of the two skills should match for this net result (they should obviously the negative of each other). The character with the highest success level “wins.” If both characters achieve the same success level, the “stalemate” result of zero (0) applies. If a tie is not appropriate to the situation, then decimal place may be rolled as explained in the initial section.

Penalties are subtracted from the skill roll directly (not through Row-5-Addition). To distinguish the standard penalties below, penalties assigned by the GM to reflect temporary handicaps are called Special Penalties.

Injury Penalty: Combat, and other activities, may injure a character. Each injury is rated in terms of Injury Levels: M5, S10, G15, and so on. A character with, for example, one M3 and one S8 injury, has a total of sixteen (11) Injury Levels. A character’s Injury Penalty is equal to the sum of all Injury Levels. For more details about injuries, see Combat and Physician. Usually injury penalties apply to all "physical" skills. In some cases, part of the Injury penalty can be ignored. For example, firing a bow with a injured foot is not impeded in the same manner as running.

Fatigue Penalty: Using Psionic talents or certain other activity generates Fatigue Levels. The GM may also assess Fatigue Levels for prolonged physical activity, such as when a character swims a swift river and then begins to scale a cliff without pausing to rest. In general, one Fatigue Level is assessed for one minute of strenuous physical activity. A character’s Fatigue Penalty is equal to the sum of all Fatigue Levels. Every minute of Rest allows a character to remove one Fatigue Level. Fatigue penalty applies to all skill applications.

Encumbrance Penalty: Encumbrance Penalty is given by the Endurance Skill. Note: This Encumbrance Penalty is only for humanoid creatures. The Encumbrance Penalty for steeds is detailed in Mounted Combat (in the Combat chapter).

Astral Penalty: Astrals of disembodied characters have a special penalty to the MLs of all skills, spells, and Psionic talents proportional to the portion of Aura they leave with the body. If 5% of Aura is left behind, Astral skills are reduced by -2, if 10% of Aura is left behind, reduce by -4, and so on. Some astral travelers prefer to leave larger portions of their Aura behind to give their body a better chance of resisting possession by an alien spirit.

Consecration Bonus: This is actually not a penalty. It is still applied directly to relevant rituals, i.e. those for a deity to whom the ground is dedicated. The bonus is equal to the consecrator's circle. Under certain circumstances, other recipes may also use this consecration bonus, for instance, Concocting an alchemical, explosive compound in a laboratory dedicated to such volatile compounds.

At various times in the course of play, the GM decides a character has earned the chance to improve a skill. Some skills may be developed by practice/study; some require training. Execute each skill roll as follows: Roll n5. If the roll is greater than current ML, increase ML by one (1); otherwise there is no increase. This may also be interpreted as a "Learning skill" roll, where everybody has an EML of zero (0) and must match the difficulty of his current mastery. I.e. the better you already are, the harder it is to improve. To improve playability, award 1 roll per gaming session. Note that the difficulty is ML, not EML.

Additional rolls may be awarded by the GM for extended idle periods, for instance in a winter camp. Or the professional life of an NPC "off-screen" needs to be simulated. In those cases, award approximately 10 rolls per month.

Characters receive a bonus when being employed by a master with a higher ML. A character getting personal instruction from a teacher or employer can add the skill of the teacher to his roll but must also subtract 10 due to the difficulty in teaching. Be careful, which teacher you choose!

Improving Specialties is a bit more elaborate. Skills list specialties with a percentage value. This percentage value gives the part of the whole group that this specialization comprises. When the skill is improved (the skill group of all specialties) all improvement may be dedicated to the specialty instead. For example, 20% Specialty could see a possible improvement of 5 points instead of 1 for the group and a 40% Specialty a poyyible improvement of 2.5 points. This implies that often fractions need to be maintained, to keep a consistent situation for specialties. To actually improve a Specialty, start as if improving the group first. If the roll fails for the group, it also fails for the Specialty. But assuming it succeeded for the group, You do not simply gain the multiple of points. Instead, only 1 point is gained. For every further point to be gained from the possible improvement, a successful p5 roll must succeed against a difficulty of all points already gained this way. Any remaining fractions can be rolled as rounded to the nearest whole number or when “completed” by the next successful learning roll.

Note: If at any time the whole skill group is developed simultaneously, any specialties that already have the lowest level reached are not improved. By treating every specialty separately, continuing rolling after the lowest level is reached is possible. This will then only increase the specialty by one point, obviously.

Example: Assume Alosyn has an Acrobatics of 15 and decides to specialize in Vaults. He manages to beat 15 one day, possibly with a teacher, to learn more. Technically, he could be gaining 5 points, since Vault is a 20% specialty of Acrobatics. The first point is already “approved” for Vault/16. He then rolls p5 to see whether he can gain another point and with a 3 on his first p5, he now has Vaults/17. The second p5 roll (for the third point) is only a 1, so no benefit is obtained. The third roll is a 9, followed by a 6, which means his p5 is at least 2, which matches the two points already gained, so he is at Vault/18. The fourth roll is 3, 7, and 3 again! Thus his p5 is at least 3, which matches his three points already improved. He is now at Acrobatics/Vaults/19. In the future to improve the specialty, 19 must be reached to improve Vaults in this manner again. In all other respects he remains at Acrobatics/15.

Gladiators are at 80%, Hunter/Trappers, Mercantylers, Pilots, and Weaponcrafters at 60% for their additional Weapon proficiencies. Clerics open their church language at 60%, if the same family, and 40%, if an alien family. The church script is opened at 60%. For those religions that have a Temple Private Tongue this opens to 60%.

Attributes used as skills serve two purposes. First, it allows for the in-world attributes to become operational out-world, when rolling dice etc. Second, it allows players to improve this skill as other skills. The attribute itself serves as the SB for the skill. Since unmodified attribute use is a case often encountered, a table is provided for easy reference and common values. A side effect is that the average person turns out to have a skill value of around five (5). Values below zero are only reachible through “bad” die rolls.
Dimensions are collected as common reference for the many skills that use them in more or less the same manner.
For finer grained numbers, observe that this a Row-5-Addition of ML zero (0) and the pure Attribute SB.

For NPCs the associated table can be used to estimate the number of different recipes he knows how to create. PCs should rather keep a book and start with what their master has given them. Self-made dabblers start with zero (0) and would need to do research. Recipes have a wide range of meaning, from classic cooking to tricks the character can teach to animals. It includes ritual invocations.

In general, learning a recipe is a roll with the student's EML. The student should have a quiet, dedicated space to study. The Dedicated Ground modifier can be added to the EML directly. The time cost assumes a student spends 12 hours per day (3 watches) on the task, and study is continuous until the recipe is mastered. The GM may assess penalties for interruptions in the study. Some interruptions, like illness or a crisis, may justify aborting the study entirely. Recipes have a circle rating, ranging from I - VI, or given as star rating. This is a direct numeric penalty when applying the recipe, e.g. performing the ritual. For learning it represents the difficulty, see the star-rating dimension. Now calculate the modifiers and make a Learn roll on the table below. Any result below zero (0) means the time was spent in vain. Particularly nasty GMs may let the PC learn something wrong without knowing.

ul.li: Mentor: Row-5-Addition of the Mentor’s SB.
Scripture: Row-5-Addition of the Scripture value. The value is directly linked to the number of pages (see dimension above). The student must be able to read the Scripture.

div.p: This scale is used often, particularly when assessing the competence of a craftsman. This scale can be extended for the truly awesome skills.

Some pre-determined skills, including their relation to occupation, their descriptions and other parameters are found here. When several listed occupations apply, use the Row-5-Addition of the Result. This does not apply to the Languages, Scripts and Musician skill group, where each time an occupation is mentioned, it indicates a separate skill. Specialties are also treated this way: as separate opening. As a convenience, a list of the used percentages is provided (rounded).

Rising takes as many seconds as listed in that dimension and during that period the character is considered prone.

Test Animalcraft when breaking or domesticating animals, and for each trick/task to be taught. The time required for various efforts is at GM discretion. PCs may find it beneficial to visit an astromancer to learn the portents before undertaking a major adventure. Such efforts take several hours, at least, to prepare. div.p: Tested when a character attempts to climb a difficult obstacle. The GM assesses a climb by the dimensions in the table. Additional modifiers should be made for slipperiness and availability of holds. If the character has climbing gear (rope and grappling hook or spikes and mallet) and can use them, increase ML. Speed is measured in feet per second. A running total of vertical progress is kept to determine when the climb is complete, and the extent of any fall. A single scale should only be rolled once, but any interruption, such as rest requires a new roll. Any negative speed result (below -5) implies a fall. Climbing speed can be increased at the price of increasing the risk. For each 5 levels of speed that are accepted as fall, increase ML by 1 point. The following falling height is evenly distributed among the attempted climbing height. Climbing is a physical skill.

div.p: The ability to perform various types of dance. Specialties such as folk or erotic dancing are viable. Dancing is very important in some cultures, and can be used to enhance spellcasting (see HârnMaster Magic). Dancing is a physical skill. Dances are social interactions. Without at least visible encounters with dances, OML is -10.

div.p: Legerdemain (Sleight of hand) is tested when a character attempts to perform a feat of manual dexterity without being detected by observers or victims. Examples include cutting a victim’s money-purse from behind or moving shells in a shell game. The victim oppose with Awareness to detect the attempt. If the victim is not paying attention, penalties apply. If the result is negative the legerdemain is detected. Awareness rolls may also be made for any potential witnesses. Legerdemain is a physical skill. The Awareness dimension is obviously modified by the “size” of the feat. Shells or a coin are assumed for the listed penalty. The Grope dimension is the time a trick takes, but mostly for larger objects – this is a combat dimension.

div.p: The ability to produce a likeness, or to assess the artistic quality or realism of a drawing or painting. Different styles and media (such as painting, fresco, pen and ink, woodcut, etc.) may be considered specialties. Cartography is a specialty of Drawing used to produce poetic maps. The quality of a map is limited by the information available to its maker. Poetic maps are more often judged by the attractiveness of the cherubs in the margins than by their accuracy. Characters with Drawing skill may be allowed to copy their memory maps in poetic style to sell or show to other PCs.

Occupations: Embalmer/80, Perfumer/40, Cleric/40, Cleric/Morgath/120, Shek-Pvar/Fyvria/80

div.p: Determines success when embalming a corpse against deterioration, and when preparing a corpse for burial/cremation. The skill also includes familiarity with local rituals; since journeymen embalmers need to travel widely, this can result in quite an accumulation of knowledge. Religious and/or cultural differences may be treated as specialties. Civilized cultures take great care with their dead – embalming is a sign of respect and honor, and has serious emotional and religious overtones. Most temples use master embalmers (either bonded or free) to oversee their burial rituals. Embalming includes limited knowledge of practical Alchemy and Perfumery. Embalmers know how to make incense and soap, for example.

Sunsign: Ulanus+1, Lado+1
OML: 0

div.p: Load is the total weight of items carried or worn, generally clothing, armour, and weapons, but perhaps also a trinket or two. Armour and weapons are listed on the Combat Profile. Total Load is recalculated as items are acquired or discarded. Detailed lists of items may be made on separate sheets if necessary. Encumbrance Penalty is the effect of carried weight on a character’s physical activities. It is equal to Weight in lbs times Load factor.

When holding breath (for more than a few seconds) Fatigue is not recovered, as is generally the case while fatigue is accumulated. The Breath factor is a factor of the fatigue accumulation rate. A factor of 10 means that physical activity that normally generates 1 level per minute, now does 1 every 6 second. Remember that the fatigue accrued must be used as modifier for the next time interval. Endurance is a physical skill.

div.p: The ability to construct and maintain mills, drawbridges, siege and castle engines, and the like. This skill does not include the ability to make small, delicate mechanisms such as locks. For construction use the Recipe dimension.

div.p: The basic distribution presented in the in-world chapter for attributes can be used to randomly generate them. They can also be a choice, depending on how the group wants to generate characters. It can also be anything inbetween, such as partly rolling, partly choosing; first rolling, then modifying; or a point based system, where good attributes are "bought" and/or "bad" attributes provide additional points to spend. For simulation purposes, the out-world values should be recorded by the players, while the characters themselves are considered to only be aware of values available in the in-world chapter. You may create veterans with these rules.

ul.li: Height: This distribution is equivalent to rolling 6d6-15 around the average given.
Comeliness, Voice, Intelligence: These attributes can be treated numerically by rolling 3d6, with sections 3-5 / 6-8 / 9-12 / 13-15 / 16-18.

Strength, Stamina, Dexterity, Agility, Eyesight, Hearing, Smell, Aura, Will: They can all be treated as 3d6 - 10.5, with the sections 3-5 / 6-8 / 9-12 / 13-15 / 16-18 / 19-21 mapping to ★ / ★★ / ★★★ / ★★★★ / ★★★★★ / ★★★★★★. The following modifiers should be applied to keep the distributions consistent:
Stamina +4 for Khuzdul, +2 for Sindarin.
Dexterity +2 for Khuzdul, +4 for Sindarin.
Agility +4 for Sindarin, +4 for Scant, +2 for Light, -2 for Heavy, -4 for Massive.
Eyesight +4 for Sindarin, +2 for Khuzdul, +2 for Tribesmen.
Hearing +4 for Sindarin, +4 for Khuzdul, +4 for Tribesmen.
Smell +6 for Sindarin, +4 for Khuzdul, +4 for Tribesmen.
Aura +8 for Sindarin, -4 for Khuzdul, +4 for human females.
Will +6 for Khuzdul.

Psyche: For Multiple Personalties a 2nd character may be generated with new Personality Attributes (only). For disorders roll severity as p5 and treat the result as penalty to any Will test resisting an outbreak.

div.p: Each character generates a number of contacts equal to the character’s Age divided by five. These contacts are in addition to any close relatives and current work associates. The GMs decides on the details, including Relationship and Loyalty.

Although most income is spent simply to survive, veterans have accumulated some savings. Assume a veteran character has accumulated 10% of total income. For example, a bonded-master Ostler, with ten years experience has (936d x 10 years x 10%) = 936d available to spend on items or save.

An occupation resolves to 5 for each ★ that is taught. If multiple occupations are learned, they add through Row-5-Addition, when applicable. In particular, Parent Occupation may immediately added, when it is the same as vocational Occupation.
Chandlers have three craft occupations at 5. Craft occupations are marked with asterisk (*) in the table above.
Gladiators and Hunter/Trappers have expertise in three weapons. Mercantylers, Pilots and Weaponcrafters have one weapon proficiency.

All newly created characters have five option points to open new skills or improve existing skills. Remember that most skills have a score of zero, so opening a (reasonable) skill or improving an open skill is the same. For each option point five points are added through Row-5-Addition. Successive improvement of the same skill work the same.
A veteran character receives three option points per year of experience; five years experience equals 5 x 3 = 15 OP. These points should be expended as other option points.

Every Shek-Pvar adds the stars of his Chantry and his Aura. During character creation these are his Spell Option Points. All Convocational spells cost 1 SOP per level, and all Neutral spells cost 2 SOP per level. For detailed spell descriptions, see HârnMaster Magic. Beginners cannot spend more than one third of their spell OPs to learn neutral spells.

Clerics may learn invocations by spending 20 Ritual Option Points. All invocations cost 1 ROP per Circle. Invocations specific to each religion can be found in the various deity articles. See Religion.
To initially enlist in a military unit, a character is assessed, with the following additions to an n5 roll.

ul.li: +1: Good referral, Equipped for that unit, Years of military experience, High demand, Strength/Stamina ★s above ★★★, Half of Rhetoric ★s.
-1: Low demand, Years over 30, Strength/Stamina ★s below ★★★.
-4: Yeoman/LB, Archer/SB, Knight/HH (Fighting Order), Patrician/MH, Huscarl/LH, High Guard/HF, Horsebow/LH, Knight/MH (Sindarin)
-3: Yeoman/LF, Guardsman/MF, Yeoman/SB, Knight/HH (Feudal), Infantry/MF, Knight/MH (Fighting Order), Legionaire/MF, Legionaire/SB, Huscarl/MF, Low Guard/MF, Guardian/MF
-2: Guardsman/LF,, Knight/MH (Feudal), Infantry/LF, Legionaire/LF, Clansman/LF, Ranger/LF
-1: Clansman/UF, Ranger/UF

div.p: One way to determine how many talent are made for a new character, the GM secretly rolls n5 and adds Aura. For example, with a n5 roll of 0 and an Aura of 5, a character would get five talents.
Trance indicates a -20 to any other skills attempted during that period.

ul.li: Charm: Roll attacker's skill plus Will vs defender's Will and reduce the defender’s Agility accordingly.
Disembodiment: Each time a disembodiment occurs, Telepathy and Sensitivity MLs increase by 1 point through Row-5-Addition.
Healing: Empathy: Add talent skill to physician’s skill at diagnosis, etc. Restoration: Talent skill replaces subject's Stamina in new fatigue rate. Heal: Add skill to Stamina for healing time.
Hex: Reduces the victims rolls by his talent skill level (literaly).
Medium: Knowing the “true name” bestows a bonus of +10.
Mental Bolt: The attacker's fatigue is 5.
Pyrokinesis: No effect on entities with Aura or Ego, including the invoker. If appropriate, roll a fire attack against combustible materials.

div.p: Sin, Piety, & Morality: If a character acts in a manner inconsistent with their god’s morality, the GM should deduct Piety depending on the extent of the sin. Sin penalties can be imposed directly, but subtle deductions by the GM are better. The GM may also adjust a character’s Morality based upon actions over time. Characters with a Piety total that equals or exceeds their Ritual Mastery are said to have Divine Grace.
Piety gain works as Skill learning, although the conditions can be "fine-tuned" instead of generic roll.

ul.li: Prayer. 1 roll.
Fasting. 1 roll for each full day. For each consecutive day, include a bonus of +1.
Confession. Recovery of 1 piety loss with the listening priest's as "teacher".
Any Mass. 1 roll with one or multiple priests as "teachers". (Priests themselves excluded.)
Donation/Sacrifice. 1 roll per 1% wealth. No more than 1 per month.
Temple Service, Quest & Pilgrimage. 1 roll per day on task. seem random.

div.p: Divine intervention is totally at the GMs discretion and the seemingly high chances are mostly from self-reports from faithful clerics.

All people are individuals that act in Hârnworld. They, particularly PCs, are at the core of what these rules are all about. Apart of the numerical attributes, a few of the only descriptive aspects should be mentioned.

Attributes are values that other people "attribute" to individuals they encounter, particularly those that they interact with for some time. The following lists those properties and the common values used for them.

Individuals should have a moral compass. Morality is a measure of unselfishness. The following serves as a guideline of the diversity found in Hârnworld, but is by no means exhaustive. Sindarin tend towards the “higher” moral standards.

Customary description of Morality include: Diabolical, Unscrupulous, Corruptible, Law-Abiding, Principled, Exemplary. They are not always applied correctly when dealing with enemies or friends. Moral description from others tend to be worse when describing an enemy.
People have a descriptive sexuality. The distribution of sexuality in Hârn is roughly 90% heterosexual, 5% bi-sexual and 5% homosexual. Other forms of sexuality may exist but are hidden.

Although Hârn has many exotic creatures, Humans, Sindarin and Khuzdul are by far the most commonly encountered. The population distribution on Hârn is approximately Human (97%), Sindarin (1%), and Khuzdul (1%).
Among encountered humans 48% are male, among Sindarin 45%, and among Khuzdul 75%. (Other individuals encountered are female.)

Every day of the year (360) has an equal probability of being the birthday of a random person. In other words: they are evenly distributed. Names of calendar months are readily available in other sections of Hârnworld.

Sunsign is a major factor for skill-affinity, but all sunsigns have advantages and disadvantages. Sunsign is determined by birthdate. The first two and last two days of each sign are termed the cusp: a person born on the 1st of Ilvin is termed a Tai-Skorus Cusp (the actual sunsign is named first). Those born on the cusp enjoy the benefits of either sign. Hârnic astrology reveals the Pvaric nature of Kelestia. Personality descriptions for each of the twelve signs of the zodiac are given in HârnPlayer. The personality of a person born on the cusp would be a blend of the two signs.
HârnWorld regional modules provide Birthplace generation tables. The GM may assign you a birthplace, or tell you what dice to roll to generate one on these tables.
A person’s Culture is determined by Birthplace. Most people born on Hârn are Feudal. Common exceptions are: Imperial (Tharda), Viking (Orbaalese), Tribal, Sindarin, and Khuzan.

The Social Class is usually not something considered random. The table shows the distribution of all classes, should a hypothetical census be taken. It may be useful to determine the Social Class of a randomly encountered individual. For some cultures a random result does not make sense (e.g. Slaves in Kaldor). Refer to the relevant HârnWorld publication.

About a third of all individuals encountered are first-born. Of the remainder, a third is a second-born and so on. For Sindarin and Khuzdul 50% are first-born and of the remainder, 50% are second-born instead. The sex and age of each sibling may be determined accordingly, with a 60% of each still being alive. To determine the number of siblings, determine the rank of the last sibling as before, but which obviously must come after the indiviual's rank already determined.
The individual’s Father and Mother represent an important aspect of an individual in a mostly feudal society.

ul.li: 50% of all people are regular offspring, the person is raised by his natural parents. Of these cases, when a minor comes of age, 60% see both parents alive and living together, 20% see either the father or the mother absent (desertion, divorce, etc.). In the remaining 20% either the father or mother is dead, in half of the cases the surviving spouse has remarried.

20% of all people were fostered; they lived with another family for social, economic, or political reasons. Guilded apprentices are usually fostered with their masters, as are squires training for knighthood. Poor families, especially those with only one parent, commonly foster one or more children with a relative or neighbor. Fostered children are usually aware of their parents’ identity.

5% of individuals were adopted by another family for social, economic, or political reasons. Adoption is generally only done if both parents are dead, but there are exceptions if parental consent is given. Adopted children are often unaware of the fact.

15% are Bastards. Parents never married, most likely because the father was of a higher social class, or one (or both) parents were already married or betrothed. Acknowledgement happens only in a third of all cases. A bastard usually lives with his mother, but may reside with father if acknowledged.

10% of people are orphans, both father and mother are deceased. Only 5% of orphans live alone, the others are either Fostered with another family/clan (80%) or adopted by another family/clan (15%). Brothers and sisters (if any) may have been fostered/adopted by another family.

div.p: It is the habit of the upper classes to spread their oats throughout the lower classes; if unacknowledged, the real father may never be known, but then again, he may be someone of wealth and power who could be helpful. Acknowledging a bastard is a significant act; the admission can have important emotional ramifications for both parents, especially to their respective spouses. In families where there is property and/or titles to inherit, acknowledged bastards usually follow the youngest legitimate heir, but dynamic characters may do better, especially if they happen to be a father’s eldest son and the legitimate heirs are weak. Many a dynastic bonfire has been ignited with such a spark.

Estrangement measures a person’s popularity in the clan, tribe, and/or family. It has a significant effect on opportunities, including any inheritance. Being the eldest child of a knight is less advantageous if he hates you. Siblings with different estrangements are often jealous of each other; this can produce interesting family politics.

ul.li: 10% are outcasts. They are ignored or may even be attacked by other family members. Of eldest children, only 5% are outcasts, and in small clans any child has only a 1% chance of being outcast.
30% are unpopular. With the likely exception of the mother, the family dislikes the person. Any birthright is/was given grudgingly, if at all. In small clans this happens only a 20% of the time.
35% are popular with their clan.
5% are treated as favorites. The individual has privileges, possibly at the expense of other siblings. Of eldest children, 10% are favorite. In small clans, 24% of offspring is treated favoringly.

div.p: A person’s relationship to the Clanhead is often more important than to parents. Hârnic clans tend to be large. Some live in close proximity. Some number in the thousands and are widely dispersed. Wealthy and noble clans are often extended. Poor clans are likely to be smaller, especially if they live in major settlements. Poor families in the same town or district may have the same clan name, but have been out of touch for generations. Except for outcast characters, the clanhead can always provide shelter and a hot meal. In some cultures, maternal relationships are more important.
The hypothetical census would have for a person: 15% father or mother as the clan head, 10% a cousin, 25% an aunt or uncle. All others (50%) identify the clanhead as distant.

The average height of a Hârnic male human is 68 inches with a variance of 5.83. The average is modified: Sindarin: -3", Khuzdul: -14". Human females: -2", Sindarin females: 1". Ivinian +1”, nobility +2”, urban poor -2”. Such measurements are often made by Physicians, while averages and variance thereof are only calculated by excentric scholars.
On Hârn, the "optimal" weight of a person depends on his height and is determined by the Physician's Guild and usually published in a yearly almanach.

The Clothiers' Guild and others have agreed on a size measure that relates to weight and is only a scale from 1-10. The apparent distribution of sizes is recorded here. Items that are too small or too big cause discomfort. A one size difference may be acceptable. The distribution was calculated on the human population alone. Non-humans were too rare, when the data was sampled, but their sizes have been standardized by the guild none-the-less.

Frame is another proportional attribute mainly used by Clothiers. It is measured in five main categories. It is determined by the actual instead of the optimal weight to height ratio. The optimal Weight : Height ratio is considered 100%.
Complexion is the color of a person’s skin. Human is for all people of Hârnic ancestry. Nordic humans are similar to Khuzdul.
A person’s attractiveness to the same species. Comeliness can be modified by cosmetics, but these enhancements usually wear off after some time. The courtesan's guild maintains these statistics.

Physical ability is assessed by the military (including their physicians) and a five-star rating is used. Non-humans often have their own physiology - that is recognized in the statistics. (The scale is extended to six stars for exceptional non-humans.)
Agility moves the body. Agility is useful for warriors, seamen, and dancers.
Dexterity is the ability to manipulate objects with the hands. Dexterity is important for warriors and cut-purses.
Stamina is the general physiological condition. Stamina determines for how long wound healing takes and also affects disease and poison resistance.

Strength is sheer physical power, a crucial attribute for combat and other physical activities, which is why military types usually assess it. It is common knowledge that additional weight leads to increased strength. However, this has not been measured accurately and not any weight leads to an increase in strength. It is also unknown whether the same relationship to weight exists for Sindarin and Khuzdul.

Physicians collect the data for the senses, often diseases or poisons affect the senses and their origin can be determined by gauging their effects. A five-star rating is used. (The scale is extended to six stars for exceptional non-humans.)
Eyesight is the ability to see in daylight. Except for nocturnal creatures (like Gargun) eyesight is reduced in the dark and that affects all activity requiring vision.
Hearing is used to sense sound. This is essential for musicians.
Smell estimates sensitivity to odor and taste. This can be useful for hunting and/or tracking, and may warn of danger. Of course, in a medieval town, a keen sense of smell may well be a curse.
The pleasantness and/or volume of a person’s voice. Excellent and unearthly voices are in high demand. The scale is provided by the Sindarin.

Some people have one or more Medical Traits, or diseases, scars, and other identifying marks acquired during life. The Sindarin are immune to human diseases, but more are considered “Sterile” than other species. The list is not complete and no prevalence statistics in the populace are given.

ul.li: Addiction: Individuals consume some substance like alcohol or a drug. The urge is hard to overcome in certain situations. When under the influence, people may become unconscious, injure themselves, etc.
Albinism: Pallid complexion, white hair, red eyes. Viewing bright light causes intense eye pain. Albinos sunburn very easily. Some people consider them very attractive.

Allergy: Common allergies are to pollen, hair, fur, feathers, wool, bee stings, or to foods such as eggs, milk, cereals, or shellfish. When the substance is nearby, a person suffers from sneezing, wheezing, and coughing. This results in reduced abilities until the allergy source is avoided or removed. Eating allergic foods can cause serious illness or death - consider this as poison.
Ambidextrous: can use both hands equally well.
Arm missing or deformed: Activities which require two hands (such as shooting a bow, or using a shield and weapon) are impossible.
Birthmark(s): may impact Comeliness, or indicate a special ancestry.
Dwarfism: Height is Species minimum minus 2-12 inches, with Heavy Frame.
Epilepsy: Individual may have a seizure if traumatized. Swimming and Riding should be avoided.
Ear: One ear is missing or deaf.
Eye: One eye is missing or blind. Lack of depth perception and reduced field of vision makes some activities difficult.
Gigantism: Individual height is Species maximum plus 2-12 inches, with Massive Frame.
Hemophilia: Blood clots much more slowly than normal. Females do not suffer the effect, but pass it on to their sons.
Hirsutism: Excessive body hair. Such a person may be mistaken for Gargun or were-creature.
Leg: One leg is missing or deformed. Such an individual can only move at 1/3 sprint speed with the use of a peg-leg.
Left-Handed: People with this "affliction" are likely to suffer some discrimination.
Leprosy: Body covered with sores/scabs. Pain sensitivity is reduced. Comliness is reduced. Leprosy is contagious.
Lycanthropy: The individual is a were-creature. Some Physicians consider this an imaginary disease, used by miscreants to scare gullible people.
Monochromasia: Severe color blindness. All colors are perceived as shades of gray.
Obesity: A person’s weight is 50% to 100% more than optimal.
Parasites: Worms, fleas, lice, etc. These are fairly common among the lower classes. Such individuals have special difficulties with social activity.
Poxmarks (healed): A person may bear scars from a disease such as smallpox.
Scars: Invariably reduces Comeliness.
Sterile: The person cannot have children.

div.p: Shek-Pvar and Priests collect the statistics for these attributes. They are not willingly shared, only few scholars have access to the combined treasure of these numbers. A five-star rating is used. (The scale is extended to six stars for exceptional non-humans.)
Intelligence is the ability to reason and articulate. Often the following descriptions are used for the star scale:

ul.li: ★ = Absent-minded, moronic, stupid
★★ = Forgetful, slow-witted
★★★ = Average
★★★★ = Good memory, clever
★★★★★ = Excellent memory, genius

div.p: Aura is Psionic concept. Hârnic philosophers believe that all living things have Aura and that the physical body is simply a place where the immortal spirit currently resides. High Aura indicates high psychic ability, and is the most important attribute for Psionics and magic (although Will and Intelligence are also vital).

Will encapsulates mental strength, tenacity, and patience. A person with low Will lacks confidence, panics easily, and has difficulty with tedious tasks. Those with high Will are resolute, confident, and stubborn.

Phobias, manias, and other mental disorders can be disruptive. The list of mental disorders is not comprehensive. Mental disorders of the same type may have different severities. A phobia is an irrational fear/aversion. When likely to be stimulated by an appropriate situation, a person's Will is tested to determine if the phobia can be resisted or not. If relief is impossible, the person may faint, become hysterical, go berserk, etc. A mania is an irrational fascination, obsession, or compulsion, usually to excess. An individual with Pyromania takes every opportunity to start a fire; with Hydrophobia he is unlikely to enjoy swimming, boating, etc. Severity of the disorder is, of course, relevant in the actions that are taken. Some disorders are only latent and the level of Severity is unknown. It is quite possible for someone with Acrophobia to climb a mountain with no problems, but panic sitting atop a twenty feet wall. Phobias are irrational.

The list is compiled by specialized physicians but also by Savorya Shek-Pvar. A prevalence is not given, nor is the chance of multiple disorders given. The list is considered harmful, if it were to leak into the public. Translations are available for physicians not versed in scholarly tongues but sufficient funds.

div.p: * The person may change personality in stressful situations, based on his Will. The primary personality is neurotic and totally unaware of the secondary personality. The latter, on the other hand, is aware of the primary personality and often takes desperate actions to try and overcome the neurosis of that personality.

Gods or goddesses may be worshiped (however laxly) by any person. While people may respect and acknowledge the existence of any number of deities, they usually only follow one, although it is possible to change religion. The religion a person may encounter depend on a lot of circumstances and depends on the birthplace. Available choices are presented in other Hârnworld publications, which also consider culture and social class. Most people tend to follow the deity of their parents or guardians.

While there are chivalrous worshipers of Morgath and corrupt Laranians, people tend to be more satisfied if their morals matches that of their deity. Churches and clerics, unaware of an individual’s true morality, may be fooled.

People may faithfully ascribe to two or more religions, provided the deities are not diametrically opposed. Some miscreants may try to subvert an opposing religion, but this is not faithful. Some rare people may consider themselves godless. Divine intervention is another word for miracle. However, the acts of deities should never be confused with spells, which are the acts of mages.

A simple peasant may possess little more the clothes worn, a knapsack containing their worldly possessions, credentials when appropriate, and a money-belt. Most travel afoot, but nobles require a horse. A person's wealth is largely dependent on family wealth, which is relative to social status. The census data compiled by the crowns provide the following table and shows three levels of wealth within each social class. The value given amounts to what a person is assumed to possess when becoming of age, i.e. a responsible subject of the souvereign. This wealth may be used on items from the Price List on HârnPlayer and the Weapon and Armour tables. Estrangement can also influence funds.

Squires are traditionally equipped by their lord when knighted. This includes weapons, armour, and a good steed. Family wealth above does not include this. Very few Hârnic folk own property. Rural freemen and serfs rent cottages and land from the lord. City homes are mostly owned by a few wealthy folk and rented to poorer citizens. Only established urban guildsmen can hope to buy a private home. Most rural households own a few sheep or goats, perhaps a cow. Some families raise pigs which are prolific breeders. Wealthier households own oxen and rent them for village work in exchange for food and labor. Only the wealthiest of peasants can afford to keep a bull or a horse.

Clothes should suit a person’s station. A tunic, leggings, hat, and sandals are bare essentials. Some folk wear a robe or gown instead of a tunic. Travelers normally have a knapsack containing portable tools of their trade. A weaponcrafter, for example, must own hammers and tongs, but carrying an anvil is unlikely. Nearly everyone carries some fire-making tools (tinderbox, or flint and steel) and a strip of cloth for a towel, bandage, or arm-sling. A waterskin is also essential.

Nearly everyone owns a knife or dagger. Clubs, bows, hatchets, slings, and staves are also common. Other weapons are expensive and “Bearing Arms” in HârnPlayer should be consulted. Few young adults can afford good armour. Military individuals are mostly equipped by their unit, but knights on feudal service must bring their own weapons, armour, and steed.

Proving identity can be difficult on Hârn. A travelling person should have papers to prove guild rank (if any) and/or a letter of introduction from a prominent person such as a lord of the manor, or a cleric or sheriff, etc. Many guilds issue a badge or tattoo to prove rank. The expensive weapons and armour carried by knights speak for themselves.

An occupation largely determines the skills a person learns during adolescense and the opportunities that follow, at least initially. Occupation is not necessarily a life commitment. Jobs can change during a life, although this might involve lengthy re-training. The occupations available depend mainly on Social Class, although birthplace and natural talent (attributes) may open or close some doors. Some vocations (Knight and Herald) are only available to high-born individuals; some require exceptional natural talent. Birthplace is also relevant; a person born in land-locked Kaldor may have a hard time running away to the sea.

Determining the chances for the occupation of a random individual is hard, since no such census data is available. The outcome would largely depend on Social Class, which depends on the occupation of one’s parents. Some children follow the same occupation or choose another at GM discretion. The eldest born survivor, especially if a favorite, would be expected to follow the family occupation. Later born offspring have more choice, especially if unpopular. As a reference, the occupations a person can choose in Hârnic society are listed, with average income and years of apprenticeship.

Guilded Occupations: Wages given are for Bonded Masters; room and board may also be provided. The employer would bear the additional cost of providing materials and supplies, but tools are owned by the master. A skilled mason-architect building a new castle, or an exquisite sword craftsman, could earn fees up to six times higher, but such incomes are rare. Apprentices receive room & board and sometimes get pocket money from generous masters. Journeymen receive 30-60% of a master's wages, depending on experience, plus room and board. Freemasters have variable incomes because demand for their services can vary. See: HârnPlayer, page 15.

Unguilded Occupations: Wages given are for average experienced workers; others might earn more/less depending on skills. Wages are dependent on the availability of labor. They also tend to be higher in summer and lower in winter.

Occupational rating is on the typical five-star scale. When completing an apprenticeship, a person is assumed to have advanced to ★★★ through his training. The occupation of the parent will usually convey a ★ rating. Attributes play a role in selecting a suitable profession. There are practical and common sense limits. A warrior with a sufficiently high Aura can certainly learn spells, but doing so requires years learning the mysteries and ways of magic.

People interested in a clerical career must visit a temple or abbey to be interviewed by the Master of Acolytes, or find a priest to sponsor the application. An appropriate Morality and a minimum Ritual knowledge are generally required, but a large donation to temple coffers may overcome a deficiency in talent. Acolyte training takes seven years. The church is a popular career for the second (or later) sons of nobility, or for devout characters of lesser birth. The complex mysteries of church doctrine are described in Religion.

Each church has holy scriptures written in a particular language and script: Churches teach this language and script to all Acolytes. Three churches perform their ceremonies and rituals in a private (secret) language in addition to their church language.

Newly ordained clerics start play knowing some Ritual Invocations. All Common invocations rated at Circle II are taught to clerics. Clerics may learn other invocations. Also see Religion. Clerics usually complete their training with little of material value. Acolytes are unpaid and the simple monastic life they lead in training does not encourage the accumulation of worldly goods. Newly ordained clerics typically own a wool robe, linen tunic and hose, leather sandals or boots, a dagger or staff, a simple ring denoting their status, and a purse of 6-36 pence.

Shek-Pvar belong to one of six ancient and esoteric sub-orders (convocations). Each convocation stresses on certain Pvaric principles because some conflict with others. Most Hârnic Shek-Pvar reside in Melderyn. Each convocation has its own chantries. Chantries vary in quality according to a five-star scale. The best are difficult to find and enter. A high Aura is required, but most applicants can improve their chance of acceptance if they have the right family connections, sufficient funds to bestow, or an appropriate recommendation.

ul.li: Lyahvi: Wind, Magnification, Visual Illusions
Peleahn: Fireballs, Volcanos, Movement Enhancement
Jmorvi: Weapon Creation, Prospecting/Mining, Lockboxes
Fyvria: Healing, Horticulture, Necromancy, Earthquakes
Odivshe: Waves, Precipitation, Movement Reduction
Savorya: Divination, Written Works, Memory Suppression
Neutral: Counter-Magic, Interworld Travel, Energy Storage

div.p: When Mavari learn how to attune to their element, they are taught to let a small amount of Principle exist within their Aura. Attunement must be done slowly and carefully, and it takes months before sufficient Principle can reside within the Aura to allow spells to be cast. Mages refer to this Aura-resident Principle as their Foundation. With time and practice, Foundations can be increased in size to accommodate Principle from other convocations. A gifted Mavari will sometimes join a convocation in opposition to his Sunsign. This gives him an advantage when learning spells of other convocations in the future, although it will impede his early career. A Shek-Pvar Satia-Mavari departs from their chantry after five to seven years apprenticeship. Masters expect Mavari to spend the majority of their time learning spells of their own convocation.

A military career provides good weapon skills, useful social contacts, and a good opportunity for advancement in society. Of course, it might also be dangerous. Only individuals with good Strength, Stamina, and Will should consider this vocation. The sunsigns Ahnu, Angberelius, and Aralius are favored for warriors.

ul.li: Unarmoured Foot [UF] Unarmoured foot are most often found in Militia formations. Such troops wear ordinary clothing and may be equipped with homemade weapons.

Light Foot [LF] Typical light footmen wear incomplete leather and are equipped with a spear, shield, and a knife or dagger. Light foot are the fundamental troop type, and form the bulk of most standing armies.
Medium Foot [MF] Medium Foot have better weapons, most likely a spear, shortsword, shield, and better armour, perhaps some scale or mail. They are nearly always better trained and more experienced.

Heavy Foot [HF] The only permanent heavy foot found on Hârn are elite High Guard units within the dwarven army of Azadmere. Heavy foot carry heavy weapons like a battleaxe and are armoured with mail & quilt.
Unarmoured Horse [UH] Lightly armed troops used primarily for intelligence gathering, courier service, and light skirmishing.

Light Horse [LH] A light cavalryman is usually equipped with a lance or spear, shield, shortsword and mostly leather armour. He can be used in the same role as unarmoured horse, or used en masse in battle.
Medium Horse [MH] Riders are well-armoured in scale/mail with a good assortment of weapons. In feudal societies, medium horsemen are invariably knights or squires.

Heavy Horse [HH] The heavy cavalryman has well-padded mail from head to foot and may have strategically located plate. He carries lance, sword, and shield, and usually other weapons as well. Heavy horsemen are almost always noble and are primarily used as shock cavalry on the battlefield.
Shortbow [SB] A light footman equipped with a shortbow, and bearing light melee weapons and a roundshield or buckler.
Longbow [LB] A light footman equipped with a longbow. Longbowmen require years of training and are quite rare. They are well paid.

div.p: Because of the pervasive military influence of the Azeryan Empire, the Azeri names for military ranks are in common use throughout Northwestern Lythia.

Five enlisted ranks are in general use. These are rarely filled by nobles, who would consider them beneath their station. Molak: the common soldier. Status and remuneration vary according to special skills and unit type. Arkalin: commands a manus of five men; himself and four Molaks. Melbrin: commands a decad of ten men; himself, one Arkalin, and eight Molaks. Molarin: commands a company of twenty men; himself, one Melbrin, two Arkalins, and sixteen Molaks. A cavalry Molarin commands a squadron. Armolarin: the most senior Molarin in a centad. He is the principal liaison between officers and men, and is often the “real” commander of a Centad.

Officers are gentlemen. A commoner rising to officer rank is also invariably knighted. There is widespread belief that leaders must be noble, although there is no law to that effect. Five officer ranks exist. Hulhurin: junior staff officer, and deputy commander of a Centad. May also command an auxiliary company. Hethrin: commander of a Centad, or a Cohort staff officer. Kurlin: senior staff officer, and deputy commander of a Cohort. Berheth: commander of a Cohort. Tharin: commander of a Legion, which has two or more Cohorts.

Light horse units have the same ranks as infantry officers, except there is no Decad command. Medium and Heavy horse units differ at Manus and Squadron level. Chalisir: any trooper in a medium or heavy horse unit. A manus will be commanded by a senior Chalisir. Kephiri: commander of a Squadron of medium or heavy horse.

Most units let individuals enlist at age 16, and discourage those over 30. Interested individuals must contact a unit. The recruiting officer will ask about the person’s background, and military experience. A recommendation from someone in the unit might be helpful, and some Knight units (including the Khuzdul High Guard) require applicants to be noble.

Having completed four years of service, soldiers may now elect to continue their military career or muster-out of the army to follow some other occupation. Guard and legionnaire units require a one year contract at the end of which a Re-enlistment Incentive may be offered to sign up for another twelve months. Irregular units have less formal contracts, most likely just a handshake or an oath, but the effect is the same.

Having completed four years of service, one may now elect to continue his military career or muster-out of the army to follow some other occupation. Guard and legionnaire units require a one year contract at the end of which a Re-enlistment Incentive may be offered to sign up for another twelve months. Irregular units have less formal contracts, most likely just a handshake or an oath, but the effect is the same.

Military wages are traditionally paid quarterly, but are listed monthly for comparison with other incomes. Considering the danger, wages are low, but armies offer various other benefits, and sometimes deliver them. These include food and shelter, and the opportunity to collect booty. The wage table gives monthly base pay. Elite units may get more, although some elite units in which men serve for honor may get less. It is not unusual for a soldier to work long stretches followed by long furloughs. Armies are generous with (unpaid) leave in peacetime. All foot units know the ranks Molak, Arkalin, Melbrin, Molarin, and Armolarin. The pay listed is for Molaks, every next rank has a pay increase of 1/4 over the previous rank on the Molak’s base. E.g. a Longbow Melbrin earns a monthly 108d. Light Horse units have the ranks Molak, Arkalin, Molarin, and Armolarin and progress 96d, 120d, 180d, and 216d. Medium and Heavy Horse units only have the ranks of Chalasir and Kephiri, of which the Kephiri earn +96d monthly over the base pay for Chalasirs.

Traditionally, a soldier may keep 2/3 of booty collected, giving 1/3 to the next highest rank, who gives 1/3 to the next highest rank, and so on. High ranking officers can get very rich with this scheme. Cash bonuses are sometimes given for long, distinguished service, or as a re-enlistment incentive. There is no typical amount, although a bonus would rarely exceed a month's pay.

Standing armies typically offer land grants to soldiers after twenty years service. Monetary pensions are rare, but “half-pay for life” might be awarded to a soldier who has distinguished himself in some way. When a soldier is maimed in the course of duty, he is discharged with a lump sum bonus rather than a pension. The amount is two to twelve months pay, depending on the nature of the injury and wealth of the unit. Few armies provide survivor benefits. A bonus of about six month's pay might be provided to a widow in exceptional cases. More commonly, the deceased's comrades will make a collection.

A cohort, ideally, consists of two centads of light foot, one of medium foot and one of light footbowmen (shortbow or longbow). In addition, there are often auxiliary units, such as companies of engineers (sappers), artillery (siege engines), light cavalry (scouts), medical, ostlers, weaponcrafters, etc. In practice a Cohort may contain from two to six Centads, each consisting of two to eight Companies. The economic realities of manning, equipping, and supporting military units have always overwhelmed the neat organizational plans of staff officers. Each centad ideally has 100 men, grouped into 5 companies, lead by a Hethrin. Each company consists of 2 decads and each decad has 2 manus.

Some states, like Azeryan, group their cohorts into legions. The ideal Azeryani legion consists of four cohorts plus various auxiliary or reserve units attached to the legion HQ. On Hârn, legions exist only in the Thardic Republic where they tend to be little more than large cohorts.

Full strength cavalry cohorts are rare. It is simply too expensive to maintain such units in peacetime. The cohort shown, which exists only in the dreams of Lord Marshals, contains one centad of regular light horse, two centads of feudal medium horse, and one centad of feudal heavy horse. From mid-spring to mid-autumn, one or two squadrons of each feudal centad might be manned by knights doing their military service. Other squadrons would be inactive until a military emergency arises. Feudal units might be virtually devoid of personnel in winter. Formally., a squadron consists of 10 riders, and is split into two manus. Most cavalry tends to be deployed in small units of squadron or centad strength and massed only for battle. There are, of course, exceptions, such as the large bodies of horse defending Shorkyne and Trierzon's borders. Imperial cavalry tends to be mostly light. Azeryan, for example, uses cavalry in a supporting role (scouts and skirmishers), as does Tharda. This is mostly due to the lack of a feudal societal class. The Azeryani do, however, hire foreign knights to serve in some special forces. Logistical problems are different for cavalry units. Auxiliary forces, weaponcrafters, ostlers, transport, engineers, and the like are all slower than cavalry, and tend to get left behind. Units, even small ones, may have their own "field households" (messes) in tow. These too, may straggle.

Healing is a widely-practiced art. Clerics of Peoni have considerable medical expertise. Nearly all lay-folk, especially in rural areas, have some understanding of herbal remedies. Most warriors know emergency treatments for battlefield wounds.

Those who practice the healing arts full-time generally belong to the Society of Physicians, a loosely-organized guild. The Society does not care much about preserving its monopoly, and makes little attempt to maintain standards. Some masters are incompetent quacks, while others are highly-skilled surgeons. However, a physician who maims or kills too many patients will soon encounter difficulties from outraged friends and relatives.

Master physicians may take on as many apprentices as they wish. There are no journeymen in the Society, nor bonded masters in the normal sense; masters may take employment as they see fit. Many masters are associated with the church of Peoni, and some dabble in the arcane arts. Most physicians confine themselves to the treatment of minor ailments. Fees vary dramatically, sometimes according to the skill brought to bear, but mostly according to reputation. Fees typically range from 3d for fairly basic first aid to 240d for “major” surgery. Medicines, provided by the Apothecaries’ Guild, and hospital care (rare) can double or triple fees.

When people get sick or wounded, they are advised to get the best first aid available, and then seek someone with a decent Physician Mastery as soon as possible. Carrying a good supply of bandages and herbal remedies is always a good idea. Hârnic doctors are far more competent than their medieval Terran colleagues. They know, for example, it’s a good idea to keep open wounds and surgical instruments as clean as possible, although they do not know why. One theory has to do with fiery, invisible elementals which can be driven off with hot water. If no doctor is available any friend can administer treatment and self-treatment is always possible (modified by Will at GM discretion).

Esoteric Medical Treatments exist. Spells: For information on magical healing, see HârnMaster Magic. Rituals: For information on divine and cleric healing, see Religion. Psionics: For information on Psionic healing, see Psionics.

ul.li: Amputate: Surgical amputation is the only treatment for Grievous Frost and may be used to halt infection spreading. The afflicted body part is removed, but a new Serious or Grievous wound is created according to the operation’s success.
Bleeder: Treatment must be continued until bleeding stops. The patient may die under treatment.
Clean and Dress: Takes a few minutes and requires water and bandages.
Compress: Apply cold compress for several minutes. Herbal remedies and balms reduce swelling.
Splint: Setting bone and splinting. Takes several minutes.

Surgery: Includes cleaning and dressing the wound. Takes up to an hour. Requires sharp knives, and a needle and thread for sutures. Anesthetic is highly recommended (patients tend to struggle and whimper otherwise) and disinfectants are a good idea too. Such items may be purchased from good apothecaries and improve Treatment.
Warming: Gentle warming (blanket, healthy person’s flesh, etc.) of the injury for a few hours.

div.p: Psionic talents are native, psychic abilities some people possess, but may be unaware of. Since it requires years of practice to properly employ Psionic talents, they are within the sphere of the Guild of Arcane Lore. Those endowed may notice some of the odd effects produced by their latent Psionic abilities to ★ (one star on the five-star scale). Some learn of their ability when another person with a developed talent is able to sense and inform them of its presence. Some talents are never discovered and remain dormant forever. Individuals who wish to became a mage are more likely to be accepted as an apprentice if they have an active Psionic talent.

Psionic Talents at ★ are dormant. Anyone with a dormant talent is unaware of its existence. No conscious development of dormant talents is possible. However, exposure to powerful Psionic events or artifacts may stimulate a dormant talent. Once the talent exceeds ★, it becomes known to the person possessing it. A dormant talent may reveal its nature with Psionic Episodes. In later parts of the dormant stage, frequent Psionic episodes can lead to apprehensions that the person is insane, and may cause well-meaning observers to attempt cures or confinement. This can be awkward when the person does not know the cause of the problem.

Once a talent develops past the dormant stage, it may be developed more or less normally. The individual must meditate (not sleep!) for at least 8 hours of a day to gain new insights. Anyone with an active Psionic talent can attempt to use it at anytime, provided the person is conscious. Using Psionic talents is tiring, regardless, whether or not the attempt is successful. Fatigue can also be accumulated after a Psionic episode. Particularly stressing invocations may cause the invoker to fall unconscious and also suffers Psionic Blindness, the complete inability to use any Psionic talent, for several hours. Sometimes unpredictable and/or unanticipated results may occur when invoking a Psionic talent. Possibilities for misfires are given in the talent descriptions. Psionic episodes occur randomly but are more likely, when a talent is used often or for extended periods of time.

Medium, Prescience, and Sensitivity are talents which may be stimulated by appropriate phenomena, which is called passive triggering. Medium may be triggered by the presence of ethereals, Prescience by imminent danger, and Sensitivity by a Psionic or magical residue/effect. If the stimulus is weak, the person is less likely to be alerted. When passive triggering occurs, the owner is given minimal information. If the person wants more information, the talent must be used actively (with fatigue being a consequence).

Two people with the same Psionic talent may wish to pool their efforts in invoking the talent. This may be done if skin contact is established by grasping hands, etc. and skin contact is maintained during the time spent invoking the talent. Under unknown circumstances ritual procedure may need to be followed in order to form the necessary “fusion” between invokers. This will become known to the affected invokers instinctively.

The following talents are known by the guild. No percentages are given, because talents are too rare to gather sufficient statistics. While Psionics are more instinctive than spells, concepts such as Spellfire Timing, Modeling, Detection, Noise, and Foci, all have application.

ul.li: Psionic Episodes: Brief hallucinations or illusions, headaches in nearby persons, sudden dizziness, people having bad luck or unusual clumsiness in the invoker’s presence.
Misfire: The invoker, or a random person/animal nearby, suffers the talent’s effect. Sometimes the invoker gets a severe headache instead.

div.p: A Psionic talent to influence the mind of another person (victim). The usual effect is to “freeze” the victim in place for a limited period of time. In order to invoke the talent successfully, eye contact between the invoker and the victim is necessary, but only for a momentary glance. The maximum distance at which effective eye contact can occur is approximately 10 yards. The effect remains in place until the attacker stops gazing at the victim.

ul.li: Psionic Episodes: Vivid dreams of faraway people and things. Dizziness, disorientation, confusion, headaches, sleepwalking, blurred vision, or mirage-like hallucinations can also occur.
Misfire: False or random information is given to the clairvoyant. Sometimes, severe headaches that cause temporary blindness occurs.

div.p: The ability to visualize events currently occurring at a remote location. A target may sense the attention of a clairvoyant. The psychic enters a trance and after the first minute gets a clear image of some object, person, or location that he is familiar with. The image may be moving and is of the current state. Sensory perception is normal but with narrow focus on the object. Clairvoyance may be used in either of two ways: Near: The clairvoyant enters a trance to transfer their point of perception to a location. The location must be familiar to the clairvoyant. Far: The clairvoyant enters a trance sand attempts to focus on a specific, remote person or object whose location may not be known. The clairvoyant does this by visualizing the person’s face (or by describing the object). There are no range restrictions, but there is also no chance to listen or smell.

ul.li: Psionic Episodes: Sleepwalking, dreams of floating through space, various “altered mental states,” Jamais vu, lightheadedness, peculiar shivers, dizziness, or a feeling of being watched.
Misfire: Extreme weakness, dizziness, disorientation, and loss of balance. Sometimes the invoker simply falls asleep.

div.p: The ability to detach the ethereal spirit from the body, which is left in a state of metabolic suspension. The disembodied spirit is referred to as an astral entity. Information about the abilities of astral entities is in Religion. It is difficult to remain in a disembodied state for long. The talent lasts for several minutes, after which the astral entity instantly returns to its body (even if it does not want to return). If the body is vacant when the astral entity returns, it reunites with its body and a Shock Roll is then made. If the body has been occupied by another ethereal while the astral entity was away, Mental Conflict occurs. Disembodiment is achieved by making one’s body very relaxed (somewhat similar to how one falls asleep). The time needed to invoke the talent is one minute.

ul.li: Psionic Episodes: Emotional empathy (crying at the distress of others) and sympathy pains (someone else hurts their hand and the invoker feels the pain).
Misfire: Sometimes the healer acquires some or all of the patient’s ailments.

div.p: Talent requires skin contact between the healer and the patient (who may be the healer). Four options exist:
Empathy: An attempt to diagnose the patient's emotional state and/or physical well-being.
