Restoration: An attempt to remove fatigue. Remove fatigue from the “victim” at a seemingly random rate. The fatigue is accrued by the talent user at the normal rate.
Bloodloss: An attempt to clot a single bleeding wound.
Heal: An attempt to increase the healing rate of one identified ailment or wound. No fatigue is accumulated, but it requires constant attention as a physician would need.

ul.li: Psionic Episodes: The individual and/or companions have unusual spells of good (or more likely bad) luck.
Misfire: The invoker suffers the effect.

div.p: Sometimes called “the evil eye,” Hex is the ability to “curse” a victim, causing them to have bad luck. If the invoker has a part of the victim (nail parings, lock of hair, etc.) increase Mastery. Such items cannot be used more than once. At the time the talent is invoked, the maximum distance between the invoker and the intended victim depends on whether the invoker has a part of the victim. If a part is available, the maximum distance is a league. If a part is unavailable, the maximum distance is line of sight. The psychic enters a trance and after the first minute reduces the victims rolls by his talent skill level. The person may be moving.

ul.li: Psionic Episodes: Very scary nightmares, the dim perception of “ghosts” here and there, a dread of graveyards, hearing voices, etc.
Misfire: Sometimes an itinerant ethereal is released into the invoker’s world. This occurs more often when such entities are hostile, violent, or in search of a body.

div.p: Ability to communicate with ethereals. Any in vicinity or whose true name is known. Mental conflict is possible. Medium is subject to passive triggering. The talent may be used in one of three ways. Each requires a trance and accumulates fatigue.
Communion: If successful, the invoker is able to clearly perceive and communicate, for some minutes, with any ethereal within earshot.
Summon: An attempt to summon an ethereal currently perceived by the invoker, or whose true name is known. This results in a Mental Conflict. Knowing the “true name” is beneficial to the talent user.

Control: An attempt to command an ethereal the invoker has summoned. Another Mental Conflict must be won. Some ethereals are beyond control. With a win, the ethereal may be commanded to perform a simple task such as answer a yes/no question truthfully within its knowledge, or dispossess a body.

ul.li: Psionic Episodes: Devastating headaches, dizziness, etc. for the individual or innocent bystanders.
Misfire: The invoker, or some randomly-chosen person/animal nearby, suffers the talent’s full effect.

div.p: The ability to project a blast of mental energy at a single mind within 25 yards and line of sight.

ul.li: Psionic Episodes: Spells/talents tend to go wrong in the person’s presence.
Misfire: Fairly harmless with this talent.

div.p: The invoker enters a trance for 10 seconds and if successful, creates a spherical Psionic field, centered on the invoker’s head. The field lasts for several minutes, but may be dissolved instantly by its creator. The field requires great concentration to maintain; the invoker is in a trance and limited to simple activities, like walking. Any magic or Psionics entering or within the field are affected.

ul.li: Psionic Episodes: A kind of passive triggering of the sense of danger. Violent dreams and/or nightmares about loved ones dying or having severe difficulties are also common.
Misfire: False or random information is given to the invoker.

div.p: The ability to determine the “fate” of a group, person, or item. Subject to passive triggering. Any positive result makes either vision comprehensible. Prescient visions can be symbolic in nature. Folklore may be used to interpret the vision. Some clerics and divinators specialize in interpretation of prescient visions. There are two active forms:

Prescient Vision: The invoker specifies the subject of inquiry. The invoker enters a trance for one hour, during which a prescient vision occurs concerning the subject. Mastery is reduced if the subject is hidden by magic, etc. Normally, the invoker lacks control over the vision, but with ★★★★ or above, it is possible to direct the inquiry somewhat. Prescience can only reveal likely future events; the future may be altered. The trance does not cause fatigue.

Sense of Danger: An attempt to assess danger in a specific location. The invoker enters a trance for about a minute. If successful, this gives a vague feeling of danger if there are traps or lurking dangers within an area that could reasonably be reached/accessed within the time frame the trance lasts. This trance causes fatigue.

ul.li: Psionic Episodes: Feelings of Jamais vu in connection with various objects are common.
Misfire: False or random information is given to the invoker, or an object held crumbles to dust.

div.p: The ability to divine information about persons by touching an object with which they have been in contact. Psychometry requires the invoker to hold the object and enter a trance for a few minutes. Psychometry is most often used to divine the age or history of an object, the identity of the object's maker or owners, magical/divine powers, etc. Another use is to determine a person’s location.

Psychometry can never be used to divine the future. It works best when queries concern the present or recent past. Mastery is reduced for inquiries in the distant past, or if knowledge of the object is magically or divinely hidden. The longer the vision lasts, the more information is obtained. A reasonable minimum is 5 minutes. (Accrues fatigue.)

ul.li: Psionic Episodes: When the person is in a condition of stress, nearby objects sometimes smolder or burst into flame.
Misfire: The wrong object(s) ignite.

div.p: Raises the temperature of a combustible, inanimate object to flash point and starts a fire. The object must be within throwing range and line of sight. Time to invoke and start the fire takes a long as it takes to throw an imaginary fire to the target. It takes a bit longer when the object is chilled or wet. Once the object begins to burn, the invoker has no control over the fire. The talent may be used to warm objects to a desired temperature less than flash point, but bad results may cause ignition. The talent has no effect on intelligent beings, including the invoker.

ul.li: Psionic Episodes: Shivers associated with feelings of Deja vu are common. Sometimes physical discomfort must be endured or a telepathic message intended for someone else is received.
Misfire: False or random information is given to the invoker.

div.p: Sensitivity is subject to Passive Triggering and may be used actively to scan for magical or Psionic residue/effects. Mastery may be adjusted to reflect the source and strength of any such effects. Maximum range at which a spell/artifact/talent can be detected is usually 5 yards. Sensitivity can also be used to attune to magical artifacts or effects. Once attunement is achieved, it usually lasts as long as the invoker stays within range of the artifact/effect.

ul.li: Psionic Episodes: Objects move by themselves, get lost, etc.
Misfire: Objects move/teleport in odd directions and at unpredictable speeds. Sometimes an object is teleported into another world.

div.p: The invoker can move objects without physically touching them. Range and effected objects are as the eye perceives them. Teleportation is impossible. It is not possible to move part of an object, unless the parts can be separated normally, such as the tumblers of a lock. Two or more objects cannot be made to occupy the same volume of space. The object to be moved must begin and remain within 50 yards and in line of sight.

ul.li: Psionic Episodes: Sharing dreams is very common. Broadcast of thought or emotion to nearby people can also occur.
Misfire: Sending a transmission to the wrong person, releasing the wrong thought and/or emotion, etc.

div.p: The power to transmit thoughts or emotions to the mind of another individual (target). Transmission range is skill level in km,, but clarity diminishes with range. The talent is invoked by concentrating on the thought/emotion for one minute. The target is specified at the time transmission is attempted; the target’s location does not need to be known by the invoker. Someone who receives an emotion will feel it – this can have an interesting effect. If a person with the Sensitivity talent is near the target or the invoker at the time of transmission, they may receive the transmission along with, or instead of, the intended target.

ul.li: Psionic Episodes: Headaches and dizziness, and rare bouts of semi-translucence, especially near Barasi Points.
Misfire: Invoker may arrive at an unexpected destination, most often on Yashain.

div.p: The ability to detect and employ Barasi Points to transfer the invoker from one world to another. Objects or living entities within Skill level in inches of the invoker’s skin may also be transferred. Less skilled users often lose things on the way. Travel is ethereal, instantaneous, and takes 5 minutes in "absent mindedness". The talent is fairly common among the older bloodlines of the Sindarin, but otherwise rare. The invoker does not necessarily know where the destination will be, although it is always a similar environment. Barasi Points are natural portals between worlds. Dozens exist throughout Kethira, although the Shava Forest on Hârn has a particularly high concentration. The environment at each end of a Barasi Point is always very similar. Unskilled users may not realize for some time they have changed locations, and may never discover they have actually changed worlds.

ul.li: Psionic Episodes: Headaches, dizziness, and dreams/nightmares involving the target form.
Misfire: facial disfigurement, skin discoloration, etc.

div.p: The Psionic ability to shapechange. The target form is rarely a choice and is nearly always an animal of roughly the same size as the invoker. The invoker acquires the physical attributes of the target form, but retains his own personality attributes. The effect lasts for several hours, but this can be shortened by another transmutation use. While transformed, fatigue is not accrued, only during the change. The change process takes 5 minutes either way and has normal fatigue for Psionics.

A few scholars may argue that the gods are figments of the imaginations of men, but most Lythians believe implicitly in their existence. Hârnic society is pregnant with divine superstition. In addition to the ten major deities, hundreds of lesser semi-divine entities are worshiped by Lythians. The powers of the deities, if not infinite, are beyond the compass of mortals. Demigods, on the other hand, are closer to humankind; their imperfections and weaknesses, their attitudes and objectives, may at least be comprehended by mortals. Demigods are of two types: those who serve one of the ten great deities by choice or compulsion, and those who serve no master. They vary in strength and attitude. Some demigods are confined to specific regions by greater beings or principles, some are associated with particular peoples or institutions, and some are semi-legendary mortal heroes. A demon is simply a demigod one believes to be evil.
Most religious artifacts are constructed of materials which are associated with the church and deity.

ul.li: Agrik: Lava, Obsidian, Steel, Jet.
Halea: Bells, Coins, and Jewels.
Ilvir: Animal hides, Claws, and Bone.
Larani: Ceremonial weapons, Armour, Shields, Rubies, Garnets.
Morgath: Human Skin and Bone, Ebony.
Naveh: Daggers, Skulls, Onyx.
Peoni: Bloodstones, Emeralds, preserved Glowers.
Sarajin: Amber, Fur, Leather.
Save-K’nor: Tomes, Quills, Lanterns, Pearls (especially Black Pearls).
Siem: Wood, Marble, Star-shaped Items, etc.

div.p: Each of the ten major deities have mortal adherents who have created religious institutions to regulate and foster their version of the truth. The organization of churches vary greatly. Each is detailed in the separate deity articles, but a few generalities can be made. All churches have a clergy and laity although a few, like the Church of Naveh, almost totally ignore the latter. Some laity may be extremely pious, but they will not be taught the higher rituals of the church. The clergy are the priests and priestesses, those who organize and administer the temples and devote their lives to serving the deity. Although often simple folk by birth, clerics enjoy a privileged social status between that of guildsmen and the nobility. All churches of the ten major deities have ceremonial levels of knowledge called Circles of Command. Most churches have seven Circles, although those without Pontiffs have only six. The table below indicates offices a member of that Circle is qualified to hold.

Those baptized in a faith are automatically I. Circle. Those entering the church as a career are admitted to the II. Circle. Clerics are admitted to the III. Circle when they are ordained. Admission to higher Circles require approval of at least three existing members of the desired Circle. This may occur soon, or it can be delayed by years of political intrigue. Churches appoint members of the clergy to permanent or temporary offices. All promotions are controlled by those with higher office, except the highest office is usually the result of election by peers. In some churches the offices of Archbishop, Primate, and Pontiff are (effectively) restricted to clerics of noble blood. People may apply for appointment to any vacant church office for which their current Circle qualifies them. Appointments are handled solely at GM discretion; a candidate’s Intrigue and Social Class are always significant.

Most churches contain one or more clerical orders and most clerics are members of a specific order. The lay followers of a deity are not required to join any particular clerical order, but those with martial skill often belong to fighting orders which are sponsored by various clerical orders. Clerical and fighting orders have their own hierarchies. Morality is a crucial attribute for clerics. Although church officials may be unaware of a person’s true Morality, deities are not so easily fooled. Clerics entering a church for which their Morality is inappropriate are unlikely to prosper, or even live very long. Circles are ceremonial ranks, whereas offices are political ranks. Higher circles are evidence of a certain level of knowledge, but in no way guarantee promotion to higher office. A High Priest is a member of at least the IV. Circle, but most members of the IV. Circle are simple priests. Although rare, there have been cases where a VII. Circle pontiff retired to end his days as a simple abbey priest.

Legally recognized churches have the right to hold their own courts and administer justice for a variety of religious crimes, including blasphemy, heresy, and witchcraft. Temple courts often use trial by ordeal to determine guilt or innocence. The penalties handed out vary from one church to another; Peonian courts rarely inflict permanent harm on offenders, but Agrikan courts are fond of burning at the stake. Temple courts must obtain secular consent to any death penalties, a formality often ignored by some churches. For more information, see HârnPlayer.

There is corruption in every church. Most churches argue that their clerics are infallible, but corrupt ones will be punished in the afterlife. This may be of small comfort to a cleric who is roasted alive on false charges of heresy. The piety and ritual rules allow clerics to perform ritual invocations without piety, although pious priests can do them better.

The fragmentation of the churches resulting from pantheism weakens their universal influence, but their power in specific regions, or among some economic groups is significant. The churches of Larani and Peoni dominate in the kingdoms of Chybisa, Kaldor, Kanday, and Melderyn. The church of Agrik is prominent in the Kingdom of Rethem. Adherents of Save-K’nor tend to be scholars with influence throughout Hârn, on Melderyn in particular. Sarajinism is the dominant faith of the Ivinian conquerors of Orbaal, while Ilvir holds some sway among their subject Jarin. Siem is primarily worshiped by the Khuzdul and Sindarin, although each race tends to focus their faith through one of two demigod servants. Halea has support from merchants and guildsmen in all states, but is most dominant in the Thardic Republic. The churches of Morgath and Naveh have few adherents; both are proscribed and covert throughout most of Hârn, except the Church of Morgathm which has enormous influence in Golotha, the principal city of Rethem.

Piety is a unit of favor with a deity and religious zeal. People accrue Piety by performing actions publicly beneficial to their deity. They expend them by publicly committing a sin. Piety may also be used to increase the Mastery of any skill of Prayer. Piety is dedicated to a single deity. Individuals can, if they wish, maintain separate Piety totals for two or more deities. Multiple worship is rare, especially among clerics. Most folk fear this will compromise the passage of their soul when they die. Remember that a major sin to Larani, might be viewed by Agrik as commendable. Also remember that the viewpoint of a church and its deity may differ; an overzealous or corrupt priest might declare an action to be a major sin, but a deity might not agree. Adherents of churches that hear confessions may be able to avoid some penalties, but penances are often imposed, especially on ordained clerics. Some people are said to have Divine Grace. Divine Grace has the following important effects:

Individuals with Divine Grace are deemed “worthy” of divine aid, and individuals without Divine Grace are “unworthy.” Hence, a call for divine intervention is more likely to succeed for those with Divine Grace. Invocations that heal injuries, cure diseases, remove curses, etc., have a Special Bonus if the subject has Divine Grace. A person without Divine Grace will have difficulty convincing a deity to claim his spirit when he dies, forcing it to wonder the worlds as a shade, or to negotiate with another deity for acceptance.

ul.li: Prayer. One uninterrupted hour of prayer and/or meditation in an appropriate temple or on other consecrated ground.

Fasting. A full day (24 hours) of fasting, which cannot include any other activity except prayer, sleep, etc. Note: starving is not fasting; individuals must make a conscious decision not to eat when food is available.

Confession. The churches of Halea, Larani, Morgath, Naveh, Peoni, and Save-K’nor hear confessions. Only confessions of “significant guilt” are worthy of piety. Confessions must be made to an ordained cleric who (80% chance) may demand a penance.
Daily Mass. Attendance at the daily church service held by most temples. Daily Mass is generally held in the early evening and lasts one or more hours. Services may be attended by anyone.
Monthly Low Mass. Most churches hold a special monthly Low Mass for the laity. The day varies by church. There is no Daily Mass on this day.
Monthly High Mass. Most churches hold a monthly High Mass which may be attended only by the clergy. The day varies by church; most have one day a month they consider more holy than any other.

Feast Mass. Held yearly on the principal holy day, this mass often lasts four hours. It is usually followed by second service open only to clerics. There is no High Mass or Daily Mass on this day. A “feaster” is a name given to adherents who attend only the Feast Mass – it is a derogatory term.

Temple Service. Some characters perform a minor task for the temple, such as cleaning out the storerooms or latrines. The service usually takes a couple of days to perform. Piety accrual is on completion and may vary with the difficulty (or unpleasantness) of the task.

Donation/Sacrifice. People may make donations to temples or sacrifices to their deity. A sacrifice must be appropriate to the deity. Siem, for example, would cast out anyone who sacrificed a life; Morgath would be very pleased. Something of high value to the individual will probably be more favored by the deity.
Quest. Character agrees to perform a task in the service of a church and/or deity. Individuals who willingly abandon the task before completion lose piety.

Pilgrimage. Character undertakes a journey to a holy site of the deity. Piety granted reflects the distance and danger involved. Because the ways of deities are incomprehensible to mortals, the piety for any act may seem random.

div.p: The motives of the gods vary. The kind of universe desired by Morgath, the Lord of Chaos, is different from that wanted by Peoni, the gentle patron of healing. The problem all ten gods face is that they cannot destroy each other without risking all their destructions. Hence, the Concordat limits the actions that may be taken. Conflict between the gods is now more or less confined to the mortal and semi-mortal planes of Kethira and Yashain. Siem has withdrawn to the Blessed Realm, and Ilvir broods alone at Araka-Kalai. Halea, Naveh, Save-K’nor, and Sarajin have established their neutrality, although each favors varying degrees of order and chaos. Peoni is effectively a non-combatant. Larani stands, essentially alone, against Morgath and Agrik. These two evil deities have not formed an alliance, but it is their works that Larani tries to undo. These divisions are not simply based on morality. The quasi-war between Larani and the dark pair is more complex than a simple epic. Agrik, and especially Morgath, represent a degree of chaos, a breaking down of order that would greatly change the worlds. To prevent total chaos, and enforce the Concordat, the other gods support Larani to survive, but not to win. To prevent all-out war, there is a Concordat limiting the interference of deities in the affairs of lesser beings. Although mortals cannot know the truth or nature of these limits, the following principles, hotly debated by theologians, have evolved to justify the limitations of the gods. These principles are not always followed precisely by the deities, are often violated by demigods, and certainly do not apply to mortal adherents.

ul.li: Principle of Ineluctability: A mortal mind cannot comprehend divine purpose.
Principle of Transpotence: Since there is more than one deity, and lethal conflict between them is possible, the deities are not omnipotent.
Principle of Preservation: The gods cannot initiate any action that might result in the destruction of the All.
Principle of Reaction: Every intervention can be countered by a morally-opposing deity.
Principle of Proxy: The gods cannot act directly against one another, only through the conflict of demigods and mortals.
Principle of Faith: The gods are reluctant to prove their existence, and use natural force whenever possible to explain their acts.
Principle of Interference: Deities do not take direct action against the adherents of another deity. Deities rather preserve their own adherents than to harm those of another deity.
Principle of Piety: Intervention cannot occur unless requested by an adherent.
Principle of Revelation: Deities cannot give unearned knowledge to their adherents.
Principle of Force: The gods always employ the minimum force necessary for an intervention.
Principle of Self-Interest: Deities are never obliged to act against their own interests.
Principle of Temporal Integrity: No deity may modify the past.

div.p: Divine Intervention is an attempt to enlist the aid of a deity to perform a miracle. Interventions are implemented by gods; if they choose to respond at all, they decide what to do. A deity may be open to suggestion, but will not take kindly to demands. A person may call for Divine Intervention at any time. A call for intervention may be anything from, “Please help us out of this terrible mess” to “Please tell me the contents of this box.” There are no limits, just consequences. An individual calling for Divine Intervention must have at least ★ Piety for that deity. Each deity has a base chance of 20% to intervene. (These statistics are collected by the individual churches and are highly subjective and significantly favor their own deity. Still, the average across all ten major deities is presented. The data should therefore be taken with a pound of salt.) Piety from two or more individuals may be combined; each may make a separate call. Calls that are trivial or unethical (for that deity) are always unworthy. Conversely, a call to do something the deity would probably want anyway is more likely to succeed and worthy. Note: Ritual skill plays no part in Divine Intervention. A pious layman has more chance of Divine Intervention than an impious cleric of high ritual. Deities are averse to leaving direct evidence of their actions or even of their existence. When a deity intervenes, it is generally impossible to prove an intervention has actually occurred. Virtually any intervention can be explained away as just as coincidence, the normal workings of nature, etc.

If the call for intervention succeeds, a 60% chance is estimated for the deity to impose conditions for the aid. The caller is given a task to fulfill in exchange for the intervention. Such tasks vary from minor services that must be undertaken within a year. Any condition and non-compliance penalty depend on the deity, the importance of the intervention, and so on. Refusal to fulfill a Condition is unwise.

If the call for intervention fails, a 20% chance is estimated to see if the deity exacts some kind of Retribution on the caller. If a retribution occurs the deity not only fails to help, but also inflicts some curse or penance.

A call to a demigod increases the chance of Intervention by 10, but also increases the chance of Conditions by 20, or the chance of Retribution by 10. Individuals may pray in the hope of gaining the favor of their deity for any endeavor. Prayers take between one second and one minute usually. The effect is to increase the Mastery in some skill by a few points. Success varies with time and piety involved.

Between this world (Kethira) and the next (Yashain) stands a shadowy “half world” known by many names, but most often as the Astral Plane or the Spirit World. Ethereals are spiritual entities, capable of existing on this Astral Plane, and moving between it and Kethira or Yashain. Kethira, Yashain, and the Astral Plane all exist in the same or nearby physical space. Passing through solid objects by an Ethereal is called “frooshing.” For many ethereals, this is unpleasant and/or tiring. A corporeal creature “frooshed” by an ethereal usually experiences an eerie, shivering sensation.

Astrals. An astral is a disembodied spirit, typically created by the use of the Disembodiment Psionic talent or the Transcendence ritual invocation. An astral maintains strong empathy with its own body because it must leave at least a portion of its Aura behind to avoid death. Because of this link, an astral entity always knows the distance and direction to its native body, and is always aware of any in the status of that body. A vacated body is comatose in a state of metabolic suspension. The body is subject to normal physical injury and can die during the absence of its astral. Should this occur, the resident and astral portions of Aura will immediately dissolute and reform as one entity in double the normal time. An astral may return and repossess its own (living) body without difficulty, but fatigue is accumulated in the ethereal state. An astral may also return to find its body has been possessed by an alien spirit.

Shades (Ghosts). A shade is created when: The physical body of an astral traveler dies; a person dies without Divine Grace and the spirit is unclaimed by any of the gods; a person dies in circumstances which require a “great wrong” to be righted before the spirit can “rest.” A shade may wander the world(s), but most often haunts the scene of its death until the “great wrong” is righted, or they are admitted to an afterlife by one of the gods.

Natural Ethereals. These are entities whose natural state is ethereal. They originate on the Astral Plane, most often by powerful sorcery or divine will, but may have a physical form on some other plane. Divine and semi-divine entities are natural ethereals, as are most elementals. Some entities are able to de-materialize their physical bodies and become entirely ethereal by an act of will, or by arcane means. De-materialization has the advantage of avoiding the risks of leaving a body behind while the spirit travels. This ability is evidence for the view, held by many scholars, that the mortal body is simply a convenient physical manifestation of the immortal Aura. This theory, if true, means that all creatures are really natural ethereals because their immortal state is ethereal.

Although usually referred to in the singular, the Astral Plane is really an almost infinite number of shifting and overlapping planes. Although movement between astral planes is almost instantaneous, only divine entities can hope to navigate this “ethereal maze” with any degree of speed or accuracy.

Ethereals have no physical attributes and cannot see, hear, smell, touch, or taste things in a physical sense. They possess only non-physical attributes and abilities, including spells and invocations. Ethereals have the Psionic talents of Telepathy and Sensitivity. They are able to directly perceive and communicate with each other, and with a corporeal entity bearing these talents. Their sensitivity to Aura also allows them to view all living things as a hazy image, day or night. When moving on the same plane, astrals and shades travel as a fast runner would and pass through solid objects at will - which is fortunate since they cannot see any Aura-less objects. Natural ethereals, especially if winged, can generally move faster than this.

Ethereals are not subject to physical fatigue, but may accrue mental fatigue by using spells or Psionic talents. An ethereal may only use talents or spells which do not involve physical action on its part. All Masteries while disembodied are subject to fatigue. Ethereals cannot be destroyed. They are immune to injury except when inflicted by enchanted weapons, magic, Psionic talents, or divine intervention. If subjected to esoteric harm, injury is translated into fatigue. Ethereals cannot recover fatigue except by dissolution. Dissolution is the scattering of an ethereal’s “substance.” It reforms in several hours at the location of the ethereal’s physical body (if it has one), otherwise in a random location or plane. When the process is complete, the ethereal regains consciousness and has no fatigue.

The natural state of ethereals is invisible. They can become translucent at will, but doing so accrues normal Fatigue per minute. This accumulation of fatigue does not by itself cause dissolution, but will increase the ethereal’s susceptibility to dissolution. An ethereal may possess a live body by winning a mental conflict with the resident Aura. Possession is easier if part of the native Aura is absent as an astral. A possessed body acquires the personality attributes of the invading spirit, while physical attributes are unchanged. All disembodied inidviduals have Telepathy and Sensitivity Psionic talents during their ethereal state. These talents are dormant in all creatures with Aura. Kethira, Yashain, and the Astral Planes all exist in the same or nearby physical space. Movement between these planes is almost instantaneous, assuming the traveler knows the paths to take which is never easy given the ever-shifting nature of the Astral planes. An ethereal move applies only to movement on the same plane. The risk of having a stranger establish squatter’s rights in the “temple of one’s body” is one of the greater hazards of astral travel. From an astral’s perspective, this is akin to breaking into someone’s house, eating the food, drinking the wine, trying on the clothes, beating the servants, and bedding the spouse. A vanquished native spirit may attempt to regain its own body with a new Mental Conflict after the normal period of Dissolution. An ongoing struggle between the invading and native spirit may cause further personality switches. Ethereals may also possess the body of a recently dead creature, thus creating a Zombie.

Each person has a soul, the non-physical portion of the person. When the body dies, the soul journeys to its afterlife. Most people commit their soul to one god who takes possession of the soul upon death. Those who die godless, or out of Divine Grace with their god, embark on a Death Journey unless “saved” by a funeral rite. All clerics are taught Passage of the Soul, a funeral ritual to help a soul make a swift journey to its afterlife. Although funerals vary from church to church and from region to region, the basic pattern is the same; a priest of shaman performs the ritual to get the attention of the god. Then the priest orchestrates a prayer (often sung) to confer a state of Divine Grace upon the deceased by gathering Piety from the attendees. Those who do not attain sufficient piety for Divine Grace are on their own as they make the Death-Journey.
Agrikans practice ritual cremation. Ashes are scattered outdoors or interred in temple vaults, depending on the importance of the deceased to the church.

Haleans practice mummification and lay their dead in elaborate tombs surrounded by their worldly goods. However, such rites must be paid for (lavishly). Haleans are cremated if they cannot afford the rituals.

Ilvirans desire to have their mortal remains taken to Araka-Kalai, but few followers are so honored. Most Ilvirans are quietly buried. Because of their belief in reincarnation, the internment occurs at dusk and the grave is unmarked.

Laranians abhor cremation. Wealthy families encrypt their dead in family vaults or communal temple vaults. Those who cannot afford this kind of treatment like to be buried on a battlefield, preferably one where they have fought.

Morgathians are the most sophisticated tomb builders on Lythia. They inter their dead in vast, extensive catacombs. In regions where the church is outlawed, covert temples to the Lord of the Undead have vaults where the Morgathian dead (and, it is said, undead) are laid.

Navehan clerics are rumored to eat their dead. Lay followers often practice ritual cremation, but other methods are sometimes used. The Navehans seem to have little reverence for their dead, reserving their respect for the shade of the deceased instead.
Peonianism is mainly a religion of rural folk. Burial is the common practice, and most Peonian graveyards are found adjacent to the parish church, or on a nearby hillside.

Sarajinians prefer cremation, or burial in stone crypts, a habit they probably acquired from the Khuzdul. In either case, they like a selection of their worldly goods to accompany them (it is no longer the practice for a warrior’s wives and thralls to accompany him). Wealthy Ivinians like to be buried in a boat, sometimes set ablaze, sometimes placed in a stone tomb.

Save-K’norans practice cremation. Their ashes are then placed in a small urn that is buried. A riddle or puzzle which reveals the location of the urn is engraved on a small memorial plaque, which is then incorporated into some stonework within a temple or its compound. Solving the riddle may find the mortal remains, and a trinket or two to encourage the game, but this obliges the finder to mention the deceased in the finder’s own “death-riddle.”

Siemians do not believe in using land for graves or memorials. The Sindarin cremate their dead and scatter the ashes in a forest. The Khuzan practice is to entomb their deceased in stone; but, if this is not practical, cremation is preferred to burial in earth.

The Death-Journey can be long and fraught with peril, depending upon how far a person is out of Divine Grace and is a series of encounters which continue until the unclaimed soul acquires sufficient piety for Divine Grace or until it is captured and taken to a deity. Each encounter automatically starts hostile, although it need not end that way, and a character might even gain an ally to escort him on his Death-Journey. Use the Mental Conflict rules to resolve encounters along the Death-Journey. If the individual defeats an ethereal of the same species, it can take possession of the physical body (if any) and end the Death-Journey.

Ghost: souls that have not completed their Death-Journey. They may wait in one place performing what acts they can to build the Piety they need to make their journey. Ghosts may help or hinder the journeyer. The winner of any mental conflict steals of the loser’s piety. The conflict resolution separates the contestant on the Astral plane, so a repeated encounter is unlikely.

Demigod: a random servitor of one of the gods. The demigod will immediately engage in Mental Conflict. If successful, the demigod brings the lost soul to its master. If the random demigod is a servant of the lost soul’s deity, the soul is admitted to its afterlife.
Ilsiri: These spirits may help or hinder the journeyer, but their behavior is alien to humans. See Siem.
Ethereal Ivashu: Ilvir has some Ivashu that roam the ethereal world, gathering souls for use in his creations. They always engage in mental conflict.

Ethereal Humanoid: A human shaman or Shek-Pvar in an ethereal state. May help or hinder the journeyer. A Sindarin will always help journeyer, after an initial challenge or contest to test the mettle of the journey.

Spells and ritual invocations should never be confused. Clerics seek to draw the deity’s attention by performing a ritual, and encourage intervention by limiting the call to a specific effect but, ultimately, they depend on their deity to act. Spellcasting, on the other hand, involves powers released by a mage from the fundament of Kelestia and requires no divine intervention. Mages are generally offended by any suggestion that a spell is miraculous. Conversely, any claim that a ritual invocation is a spell would be construed by most clerics as an admission of blasphemy.

Ritual is a skill which reflects an individual’s knowledge of church dogma, holy scriptures, chants, songs, and mysteries. There is a separate Ritual Skill for each deity. It is used by clerics for performing ritual invocations. Individuals may, theoretically, have Ritual for two or more deities. Learning Rituals assumes the individual in question has received some basic instruction in the church mysteries and been baptized into the faith. Ritual Mastery can only be improved by learning new invocations, reading Holy Tomes, or performing an invocation in an adverse situation or in ritual church duty.

Ritual invocations are ceremonies that “encourage” a deity to intervene with a miracle. They originated as a means for clerics to impress their laity or potential converts. These uses are still practiced, but many invocations work equally well (often better) to subdue those who oppose a cleric’s deity. Such use is tacitly approved by all churches, since the “proxy wars” of mortals is an acceptable method of conflict among deities. Theoretically, anyone may learn the rituals of any Circle, but most churches will teach them only to ordained priests. The rituals were once closely associated with a specific circle, higher rituals being the exclusive knowledge of higher circles. They are still classified in this way, but “leakage” of knowledge over the centuries has eroded this restriction. Today, the invocations of any Circle can be taught to any ordained priest.
People may perform any invocation they know. Invocations can be learned in one of three ways: from a mentor, from holy scriptures, or by divine revelation.

ul.li: Mentor training. Most invocations are learned from another cleric who knows it. Both the student and mentor must be fluent (★★★) in a shared language.

Holy Scriptures. There are a wide variety of holy writings, parables, songs, poems, and teachings that can be thought of as Holy Scriptures. Church archives are filled with such written works and clerics consult them to expand their knowledge of dogma and ritual. Invocations can be learned from Holy Scriptures if they are written in a known language and script, or a reliable translator must be available.

Divine Revelation. In rare cases, a deity may wish to provide knowledge of an invocation to any adherent, perhaps even a lay adherent. Such revelations are handled at GM discretion, but are only likely to occur if an individual succeeds on a Divine Intervention roll.

div.p: To learn an invocation, a person must spend 5 days per Circle. That is, for a III Circle invocation, a person spends 15 days. (The number of watches it takes is 45.)

It should not be assumed that clerics are the only people with access to ritual invocations. The Morgathian Prophet Balsha, for example, received no formal training in the tenets of the Morgathian Church, yet miracles were invoked in his presence. Most clerics feel a prophet appears when a church needs to be steered away from a path of action which does not please its deity. Of course, one person’s prophet is another person’s heretic.

Temples are always consecrated ground, and certain areas such as crypts and graveyards can be made holy to a specific deity by the ritual invocation Consecration. Peoni and Larani are allied and oppose Agrik. Morgath, the Lord of Chaos, opposes everyone, but can be, in some circumstances, “allied” with Agrik. All other gods are neutral, but tend to favor Peoni and Larani. An invocation call usually consists of a quick prayer or chant, but can involve (if time permits) construction of an altar, burning of incense, an appropriate sacrifice, etc. The intent is to perform a ritual which is less likely to annoy the deity. It is said the powers of Naveh and Morgath arise at night and slumber in the light, and those of Sarajin are highest amid ice and snow.

ul.li: Deity: Common. Circle: II. Range: Touch.

div.p: Initiates a new convert, who must be willing, to the faith. The ceremony involves a laying on of hands and dabbing with Holy Water, or other consecrated substance. Takes 15 minutes and the convert may immediately gain piety unless he already was initiated, in which case it has no effect.

ul.li: Deity: Common. Circle: II. Range: Touch/Sermon.

div.p: A ritual to bestow piety on the subject. The piety is transferred from the cleric to the subject(s). Blessing may (optionally) be used to neutralize the effect of a Hex Psionic talent or a Curse invocation. Takes 1 minute and grants ★ Piety improvement to all within hearing range except those performing the ritual. This additional Piety is lost like fatigue. Multiple castings cannot bring the current addition beyond a one star addition.

ul.li: Deity: Common. Circle: II. Range: Self.

div.p: An attempt to establish a close spiritual relationship with the deity. The cleric hopes to earn the deity’s favor, reflected by receiving bonus Piety. Takes 1 minute and grants ★ Piety improvement to the caster. This additional Piety is lost like fatigue. Multiple castings cannot bring the current addition beyond a one star addition.

ul.li: Deity: Common. Circle: II. Range: Touch.

div.p: An invocation to allow adherents of the same deity to voluntarily transfer piety to the invoker. The intent is to give the cleric more piety for any desired use. All donors of piety must touch the invoker. Takes 15 minutes and grants Piety. This additional Piety is lost like fatigue. Multiple castings cannot bring the current addition beyond one star.

ul.li: Deity: Common. Circle: II. Range: Touch.

div.p: A marriage ceremony which typically lasts one hour. Both the groom and bride must be of the same religion, or one spouse must be baptized in the other’s faith before marriage. The ceremony blesses and awards to each spouse the chance to improve their piety from the deity, unless either is already married in that religion.

ul.li: Deity: Common. Circle: II. Range: N/A.

div.p: A funeral ceremony to aid a soul to make a quick and uneventful death journey. The intent is for the cleric and/or any attendees to give the departed sufficient piety to ensure Divine Grace. Individuals may give additional piety by special prayer, etc. This takes 15 minutes to perform and grants one departed soul ★ Piety improvement. Multiple castings have no further effect.

ul.li: Deity: Common. Circle: III. Range: 50 feet.

div.p: Creates a feeling of the presence of the deity. In crisis situations, the effect is to cause all persons within Range who are not adherents of the deity to suffer a few seconds of non-action immediately, effectively pausing. Any ongoing skill attempt without reasonable waypoints must be restarted. The invocation may be limited to specific individuals touched by the cleric. Both forms take 10s to perform.

ul.li: Deity: Common. Circle: III. Range: Self/Touch.

div.p: Takes 1 minute and grants ★ Stamina improvement to one subject (usually a friend) within Range. This additional Stamina is lost like fatigue. Multiple castings cannot bring the current addition beyond a one star addition.

ul.li: Deity: Common. Circle: III. Range: Self.

div.p: Allows the cleric to speak and understand any language. Takes 5 minutes and lasts for 30 minutes. This addition is lost like fatigue after that. No permanent learning enhancement.

ul.li: Deity: Common. Circle: III. Range: Earshot.

div.p: Allows the cleric to perceive a lie when talking with someone. Truthsense cannot force a person to speak to the cleric. Takes 1 minute to cast and then lasts for another 5 minutes. Effects the caster only and what he hears. Affects commission and omission lies in the same way.

ul.li: Deity: Common. Circle: IV. Range: Self.

div.p: One Question may be asked of the Deity. An attempt to discover the will of the deity. Some clerics prefer to Summon a divine servant of their deity and ask it questions with Divination. A summoned being can be asked three questions. Takes 5 minutes to enact (during which the questions must be posed). A minor wound of ★ levels is always received.

ul.li: Deity: Common. Circle: IV. Range: Earshot.

div.p: An attempt to invoke the displeasure of the cleric’s deity upon one named victim. Curses cannot kill nor be randomly directed. A curse is usually a short, simple declaration. The Medical/Psyche tables can help inspire effects to the caster. Takes 5 minutes to enact a penalty of ★. This penalty is lost like fatigue. Otherwise works as Psionics/Hex. Multiple castings cannot bring the current addition/subtraction beyond one star. If hours are used instead of minutes, a random medical/psychic problem is created and the range is one league. The caster will receive a wound of the same level (including severity), which will heal normally.

ul.li: Deity: Common. Circle: IV. Range: 50 yards.

div.p: Allows the cleric (only) to perceive all ethereal phenomena within Range as faint, colored lights for Duration. The Summoning invocation may be used on a revealed ethereal with a bonus of ★. The ritual may be enacted for as long as desired. Caster is at a penalty of ★ for everything that does not involve ethereals.

ul.li: Deity: Common. Circle: IV. Range: Unlimited.

div.p: Calls forth a specific denizen of the cleric’s deity. The more powerful the denizen, the more difficult it will be to summon. If the ethereal has already been perceived by the Revelation invocation, Summon Mastery is improved by ★. A summoned denizen will appear after the ritual is completed. It may be asked three questions with Divination, or banished with Command, etc. It takes 30 minutes to enact this ritual. The will of the ethereal is a penalty to the skill roll.

ul.li: Deity: Common. Circle: IV. Range: Earshot.

div.p: Cleric perceives the presence and location of any holy artifact within Range. The artifact emits an ultra-sonic hum audible only to the cleric. This takes 1 minute to give a preternatural hearing attribute for holy artifacts of ★★★★★, which will hum at ultra-sound at conversational volume. This attribute dies down as fatigue.

ul.li: Deity: Common. Circle: V. Range: 50 feet.

div.p: The ability to control/banish all divine servants within Range. Clerics can command only the servants of their own deity. Hostile servants of the cleric’s deity may be banished. Servants of other deities are not driven off, but will feel uncomfortable and, if not well-motivated to remain, probably leave anyway. Friendly servants may be commanded to perform one simple task. This takes 10s to enact. It affects only one servant at a time but the caster chooses which.

ul.li: Deity: Common. Circle: V. Range: Touch.

div.p: A ritual to sanctify an object or place. Consecrations last indefinite and may be removed by another consecration, but with a special penalty of ★★, but for rituals of different deities this is at a penalty of ★★★★★ if the invoker is an adherent of another deity. Permanent consecrations can never be removed, except by physical destruction of the object.

Holy Water: consecrated water, used in several invocations. Three churches use other substances: Agrikans use ash; Haleans use perfumes; Morgathians use human blood. Each dose requires the ritual to be 5 minutes long; one charge is 3 ounces.

Holy Tome: a sacred written work which may grant the reader an increase to Ritual Mastery. These tomes have a star rating, each providing a more profound improvement chance for the Ritual skill mastery. Each volume requires the ritual to be 15 minutes long. Non-consecrated books do not grant immediate learning rolls.

Holy Artifact: a consecrated artifact, typically a staff, rod, ring, amulet, belt buckle, brooch, etc. Artifacts store a known invocation for instant activation on command. Cleric determines the number of charges to install – each charge takes a casting time of 5 minutes times the Circle. Hence, storing three charges of a Circle V invocation cost 3 x 5 x 5 = 75 minutes. Use of an artifact generally requires some sort of triggering or activation. Most often, this is done by speaking (or thinking of) a particular key word or phrase. Invoking the ritual requires comparing piety against 5 times the Circle embedded.

Holy Place: sanctifying a site to the deity, such as a temple, graveyard, site of a martyrdom, etc. The location may already have been sanctified to another deity. The casting time is 2 minutes for each square yard to be consecrated. The area to be consecrated must be walked upon during the ritual. Any version of the ritual must be completed within one watch.

ul.li: Deity: Common. Circle: V. Range: Unlimited.

div.p: May only be performed on a subject of the same religion who has lesser rank and Circle. Strips the subject of rank and responsibilities within the church and notifies the deity that the subject is out of favor. Deity might not agree with the action and may, especially in cases of impiety or corruption, penalize the invoker instead. Circle reduction is as far as the caster is authorized to invoke by the church.

ul.li: Deity: Common. Circle: V. Range: Touch.

div.p: Seeks to banish a possessing spirit from a victim. The ceremony requires frequent laying on of hands and Holy Water. The invocation involves Mental Conflict with the possessing spirit, modified by ★★. Casting time is 5 hours.

ul.li: Deity: Common. Circle: V. Range: Self.

div.p: Allows the invoker’s soul to temporarily depart the body which is left in a state of metabolic suspension. The disembodied soul functions as an Astral Entity for Duration. This takes 10 minutes and lasts for 5 hours. At the end the pull-back is near instantaneous. Fatigue applies.

Physical conflict is an important aspect of Hârnic culture. The following compilation is an extract and modernization of the anonymous treatise The Colloquium of the Four Veterans. It is clear that the author must have witnessed several of the recent Hârnic wars and extensive knowledge of conflicts with barbarian tribes. Only the essence of this four volume treatise is captured here. It is treasured among scholars.

Weapon: Some weapons are restricted by region, race, and custom. (C) Chivalric (noble) Weapon; (T) Tool/Peasant weapon; (M) Also missile weapon, data given here is for use as Melee weapon, for use as Missile weapon see later; (R) Rare Weapon (on Hârn); (G) Gargun Weapon; (S) Sindarin Weapon; (L) Long Weapon. Attacks at 5 foot range and cannot Attack closer.
Skill: Combat Skill to use the weapon.
WT: Weight of the weapon in pounds. Trace items (arrows, slingstones, etc) are presumed to weigh 0.1 pounds each.

WQ: Weapons are rated for quality. Sturdy all-metal weapons like swords have higher ratings than hafted weapons like spears. WQ represents the chance a weapon breaks in certain combat situations. Higher quality weapons cost more.

HM: Hand Mode penalties. All weapons, except Bows and Blowguns, can be used one-handed. There is no bonus for two-handed use, but some weapons are penalized when used one-handed. Unless a person is ambidextrous, all weapons (except Shields) used in the secondary hand (left hand for most) also have a Hand Mode Special Penalty.

B/E/P: The impact (damage) of a weapon when it strikes. Weapons may have impact ratings for two or three Aspects: Blunt (B), Edge (E), and Point (P). A - rating indicates the weapon does not have this Aspect. A zero (0) rating means the weapon has the Aspect, but impact is +0. Point aspects in brackets are optional; if chosen, WQ is reduced by one (1). This is a "weapon-build" option.

Price: The retail price for average quality weapons. Higher quality weapons roughly double in price for each addition point in WQ. The source for weapons is a Weaponcrafter, except F (Fletcher), H (Hideworker), M (Metalsmith), or W (Woodcrafter). Individuals with related craft skills can make/repair their own weapons, but rarely with WQs as high as listed.

Armour can be defined as any article of clothing capable of reducing the damage done by weapon strikes. Even plain cloth can help to prevent a blade from cutting. Higher levels of armour protection cost significant amounts of money and the extra weight carried increases Encumbrance. The nature of this trade-off between armour types tends to reflect economic and technological realities, although cultural preferences are also a determinant. Some cultures favor heavy armour, others prefer light armour, and a few consider wearing any armour to be cowardly. Climate is also a consideration; wearing heavy, padded armours in a tropical climate is simply too exhausting to be practical. Different types of armour are usually worn in overlapping layers, such as Surcoat (cloth) over Mail over Quilt. The protective values of each layer are added together to determine total protection. Moreover, some body parts may benefit from two layers of the same material. For example, a warrior wearing a Mail hauberk and leggings, has double mail coverage for the Thigh, Groin, and Abdomen.

Combatants must find a balance between the protection offered by armour and the Encumbrance penalty it brings. Mail, Scale, and Plate armours are heavy. It may be tempting to wear multiple layers of Cloth or Quilt, but this is highly encumbering and especially fatiguing on a hot day. Each extra layer of Cloth or Quilt (except where they naturally occur from overlapping garments) incurrs a Special Penalty.

The table assumes average quality (0) materials. Armour materials can be purchased at higher or lower qualities. The effect of these ratings (maximum +4) is to increase or decrease all protective values by the quality rating. That is, a +1 mail Hauberk has protective values of B3, E9, P6, and F2. No armour aspect can be reduced below one (1). Some Jmorvi Shek-Pvar with weaponcraft skill can produce enchanted armour. Such pieces are rare and have +1 quality per level of enchantment.
Items: Cloth and Quilt items are made by clothiers, leather by hideworkers, and all other items by weaponcrafters.
WT: Armour weight (lbs) for an average sized person.
Price: Typical retail selling price for an item of average size and quality.

Coverage: Strike locations (body parts) covered by the armour piece. Ab: Abdomen, Bk: Back (Rear Tx Ab), Ca: Calves, Ch: Chest (Front Tx Ab), El: Elbow, Fa: Face, Fo: Forearms, Ft: Feet, Gr: Groin, Ha: Hands, Hp: Hips, Kn: Knees, Nk: Neck, Sh: Shoulders, Sk: Skull, Th: Thighs, Tx: Thorax, Ua: Upper Arms.

ul.li: Cloth: heavy, coarse cloth, typically buckram or serge, worn over or under other types of armour, or alone as everyday garb. Fine linen clothing offers negligible armour protection.
Leather: soft leather or animal hide. Worn by itself, or as a base for Ring/Scale armours.
Quilt: two layers of cloth, stuffed with wool or straw, then stitched together. It is equivalent to Fur which some animals have as natural armour.
Kurbul: Azeryani name for thick leather hardened by boiling in wax or oil to produce a lightweight, resilient leather-plate for spot protection.
Ring: leather, reinforced by intermittent metal rings, strips, or studs.

Mail: butted, coiled, or riveted metal rings, linked together. Mail is lighter and more flexible than other metal armours, but is almost useless against Blunt and Fire strikes. Quilt is usually worn under Mail.
Scale: leather, reinforced by a continuous layer of thin, overlapping metal plates.
Plate: rigid, continuous, steel covering. Articulated, full-plate armour does not exist. Plate is expensive and is used mainly for helms and spot protection.

div.p: Strike location is important for two main reasons. First, only the armour worn at the location struck is relevant. Second, injury effects vary by location; a blow to the skull is more serious than a blow to the foot. The percentages allocated to body parts do not reflect the relative size of that part, since the head, arms, or groin are favored targets. Combatants can influence Strike Location by targeting their aim. Although combatants instinctively turn to face the most imminent threat, some armour only covers part of a strike location - a breastplate, for example, only covers the front of the thorax and abdomen. In random situation, where it is hard to determine whether the front or back of a strike location is struck, experience shows there is a 75% chance of being struck on the front side. An asterisk (*) indicates that Stumble or Fumbles may apply.
The accuracy and impact of missile weapons depends on missile type and range. These effects are noted on the table.

A battle is a noisy, confusing, scary place. The clash of arms, shouting, screaming (often some whimpering and dull thudding) can make it difficult to hear commands and cries for help. For this reason combatants do not always do what their superiors want them to do. Battle experience, discipline, and morale are three ambiguous, but important, elements in any battle. All these factors are accounted for by Morale, which benefits individuals with high Morale and is detrimental to combatants with low Morale. Having been prone in a Combat situation applies a penalty of ★★ to Horse Morale, which fades away.
Normal: A combatant with normal morale behaves without constraint, selecting and executing any reasonable action option.
Cautious: A cautious character will not Engage, must choose Pass if engaged, and will not Counterstrike.

Desperate: Combatant tries to conclude the battle, one way or the other, as soon as possible. Until the situation changes and a new Morale Test is passed, the combatant selects the most aggressive option available.

Broken: The individual is unable to fight in any useful way. The only available options are flight or surrender. Flight is normally preferable; surrender is a last resort. If neither is feasible, the individual makes a Rest or Pass action option, but can defend if attacked except that Counterstrike is prohibited.

Rally: The indivudual has enough character to support others in their Morale. He may provide his success to Morale rolls of others he can communicate with. This is valid for a synchronous Morale roll only. This may be augmented by Rhetoric.

Berserk: This is a special state of battle-frenzy. Any combatant who enters this mode will take the most aggressive action available for Attack or Defense, adding ★ to Attack Mastery subtracting ★ from Mastery to defend. Further Morale rolls are ignored until the battle ends. Some combatants may have a cultural heritage of berserking, or a particular reason to go berserk.

Combatants who sustain Serious or Grievous wounds may die during the healing routine. On the other hand, various types of magic, miracles, Psionics, and potions can improve healing. The following wound types exist and individual wounds are tracked with their location. Effects on the use of the corresponding part are described below.
★: Minor. Wounds only have wound penalty.

★★: Serious. Wounds of this type also have minor effects on neighbouring detailed body parts at ★ less. Any activity involving these body parts are at the appropriate penalty. These “effect” wounds do not heal separately.

★★★: Grievous. The detailed body part cannot be used, serious use effects on neighbouring detailed body parts, and minor on main parts. These “effect” wounds do not heal separately. Minor effects are at ★★ less than the Grievous, while serious are ★ less.

★★★★: Incapacitating, the main body part cannot be used, serious use effects on neighbouring main body parts. (For head this means unconsciousness and for thorax imminent death.) Serious effects are at ★★ less than the Incapacitating.

★★★★★: Destroyed, the main body part lost its integrity, Grievous use effects on neighbouring main body parts. (For limbs this means at least severed. Thorax is split open or spinal cord severed. For all but the extremities this means instant death. For all other body parts, death is probably imminent due to the side effects.) Grievous use effects are at ★★ less than the Destroyed.

Fumble/Stumble: A wound level ★ above Dexterity on an arm causes any object held to be dropped, a Fumble. A wound level ★ above Agility on a leg causes the victim to fall down, a Stumble. A character with wound level of less than ★★ above Dexterity is eligible for a Grope action to pick up any object dropped. A character that dropped to a Stumble but with a wound less than ★★ above Agility is likewise able to get back up. If the wound level exceeds these ★★ the pain and structural damage preclude recovery.

Any wound needs to heal its injury points. This depends on Stamina; medicine may improve the healing rate. A physician may attempt to find or create the correct medicine but his skill does not add to the healing directly. A serious wound may become infected until it turns into a minor wound. An infection is a daily attack on the wounded area with a level of the wound, defended against with Stamina. Medicine applies in the same way as for minor wounds, but it harder to obtain. A penalty of ★ is suitable. Any injury points gained through the infection is added to the original wound. This may turn the wound into a grievous wound. A grievous wound is a bleeder or otherwise makes the body lose vital fluids. Bloodloss is treated as a separate injury. Note that the circulatory system is incapacitated with points in excess of ★★★ as other body parts are. The circulatory system itself will not turn infectious. Treatment by physicians depend on the location. Some locations are incurable by Hârnic physicians. For multiple bleeders only take the maximum in the same extremity, but add those for different extremities. Incapacitating and destroying wounds have no additional effects over the bleeder and infection dangers.

The healing routine assumes a character will mainly be resting during the healing process. If a character gets involved in unreasonable physical exertion during Healing, the days of rest accumulated since the last day are forfeit; wounds are often aggravated or reopened by premature activity. Injury and Encumbrance penalties are ignored during Healing. Fatigue penalty (if any) are applied – injured characters are supposed to get lots of rest.

The standard treatments mostly known by all still need to be applied and detailed, so a physician's diagnosis is always necessary. “Destroyed” wounds may be treated as incapacitating, with a Bonus on Diagnosis of ★. Note that the usage effects on bordering regions needs to be treated as well.

Fire and internal system damage is treated as frost, but some treatments may not be applied, because they will kill the patient. I.e. cleaning and dressing an internal organ is not possible for Hârnic medicine. A secondary treatment to sterilize and seal a Minor or Serious wound is Cauterization. It cannot be used on Grievous or worse wounds. The procedure is done after a wound’s treatment has been established by the normal treatment rules. A metallic object and fire are required. Cauterization is attempted at Physician Mastery add ★. The effect is to close the wound and modify the Healing Rate a second time. Cauterization cannot be undone or re-attempted. It always leaves a nasty, broad scare and Comeliness effects may be applicable. Amputations and immediate cauterizations stop infections.

Diseases and Toxins come in various forms. All of the below characteristics are subject to improvements by a knowledgeable physician. Some poisons and ailments may be subject to infections. Deterioration: This is the speed at which wound points are accrued. This can be modified by Stamina. Maximum Injury: The maximum amount of injury the wound will cause, after deterioration has set in. Note that healing may prevent the maximum to actually be reached. Heal time: This is the speed at which wound points are reduced. Assume this to set in at the same time deterioration sets in.
